The Metropolitan Police issued the announcement.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster, 62, who left the corporation in April, faces three charges over alleged activity between December 2020 and April 2022. He is due in court on Wednesday.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp. The offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978. They carry a maximum penalty of six months imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine.\n\nA Met Police spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London, has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation. The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on November 8, 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, June 26, following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, July 31.\n\n\"Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Edwards was arrested on 8 November 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July.\"\n\nThey continued: \"Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nEdwards, a married dad-of-five, left his BBC role behind earlier this year.\n\nThe BBC shared this statement in wake of his resignation: \"Huw Edwards has resigned and left the BBC.\n\n\"After 40 years of service, Huw explained that his decision was made on the basis of advice. Mr Edwards will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday 31 July 2024. We remind all that proceedings are active, and the defendant has the right to a fair trial.\n\n\"It is extremely important that there should be no reporting, commentary, or sharing of information More info\n\nFormer BBC presenter Huw Edwards has appeared in court, facing charges of creating indecent images of children.\n\nThe 62 year old is accused of committing the three offences between December 2020 and April 2022. The seasoned broadcaster allegedly had 37 photographs on WhatsApp, including six of the most severe category.\n\nMr Edwards, currently out on bail, made his appearance at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday. He was seen wearing a dark suit, a blue tie and dark sunglasses.\n\nREAD MORE: Former BBC newsreader Huw Edwards charged with three counts of making indecent images of children\n\nThe Metropolitan Police confirmed in a statement that he was arrested in November last year and charged on June 26. According to the charge sheet, Mr Edwards is alleged to have six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp offences that contravene sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978.\n\nThe images are claimed to have been shared via WhatsApp. If convicted, he could face a maximum penalty of 10 years' imprisonment, reports the Mirror.\n\nA spokesperson for the Metropolitan Police stated: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation. The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on 8 November 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, July 31. Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nBefore leaving the BBC in April due to health reasons, Mr Edwards was one of the corporation's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors. His career highlights include anchoring the News At Ten for two decades and leading coverage of significant national events, such as announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting her funeral.\n\nAccording to the latest annual report, he was the BBC's top-earning newsreader, with a salary range of \u00a3475,000 to \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24. This pay covered 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election specials and other television programming.\n\nIn 2017, it was revealed that Mr Edwards was among the BBC's highest earners, with an income of \u00a3550,000. However, following public outcry over the pay gap between some of the broadcaster's male and female stars, he agreed to a pay cut.\n\nGet all the latest and breaking news in Yorkshire by signing up to Edwards, who left the BBC in April, is accused of having 37 images on his Whatsapp from an alleged period between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures, and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp. The offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978 and if found guilty he could receive a maximum penalty of six months imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine per image.\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesman said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation.\n\n\"The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat. Edwards was arrested on November 8, 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, June 26, following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, July 31.\"\n\nThe police statement added: \"Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\" Join our WhatsApp news community here for the latest breaking news.\n\nEdwards was long one of the corporations highest profile and highest paid presenters before he resigned in April after 40 years of service on \"medical advice\" from his doctors. He had not been seen on air for months after it emerged that he was accused of paying a 17-year-old for images. \"making indecent images can have a wide definition in the law and can include opening an email attachment containing such an image, downloading one from a website, or receiving one via social media, Source: REUTERS\n\nFormer BBC TV most senior news presenter Huw Edwards, a household name in Britain, has pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent pictures of children.\n\nEdwards, 62, admitted the offences at a hearing at London's Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday. He spoke only to confirm his name, address and date of birth.\n\nWhen asked if he wished to indicate a plea to the three charges, which relate to three different categories of indecent images, Edwards replied: \"Guilty\".\n\nWhat did Huw Edwards do?\n\nProsecutor Ian Hope said the 41 still or moving images were sent to Edwards on WhatsApp by an adult male between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nThe prosecutor further said that seven of the 41 images were of the most serious kind and that two of that seven were pornographic videos of a child possibly aged seven and nine years old.\n\nCharges against Huw Edwards?\n\nEdwards is accused of having six category A images, the most serious classification in English law of indecent images, on a phone.\n\nHe was also accused of having 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs. He could be jailed for up to 10 years.\n\nEdwards, who was BBC's most high-profile and best-paid news anchor, left the BBC in April. He was one of the main presenters on BBC One's Ten O'Clock News, and was often chosen to front coverage of major national events.\n\nPolice charged Edwards last month. He was arrested in November last year, a statement by London's Metropolitan Police said.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on November 8 2023. He was charged last month.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Mr Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978. If found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of six months imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine.\n\nA Met spokesman said: \"The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on Nov 8 2023. {"uri": "8250251350", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "08:36:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T08:36:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T08:36:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13687509/huw-edwards-arrest-secret-friends-child-porn-charges.html", "title": "Huw Edwards kept his arrest 'completely secret' from friends", "body": "Huw Edwards kept his arrest 'completely secret' from his friends for eight months, MailOnline can reveal today.\n\nEdwards is due in court in central London tomorrow having been accused of child pornography offences after 37 indecent images were allegedly shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\nBut any police involvement was a total mystery until yesterday evening, when Scotland Yard revealed he faces three counts of making indecent images of children relating to offences said to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nOne former colleague and friend told MailOnline: 'Huw kept his arrest completely secret'.\n\nThey said that like everyone else they had seen the statement from the Met Police in July 2023 that said detectives had not found any evidence of criminal activity when the scandal broke and he was suspended from his job.\n\n'It turns out he was arrested four months later and nobody knew. I had no idea until he was charged', the friend from the BBC said.\n\nAnother former colleague of the star said: 'It's a mess - and tragic for all concerned'.\n\nFormer BBC host Huw Edwards has been charged with making indecent images of children. Friends said they had no idea he had even been arrested\n\nHuw Edwards and his wife Vicky, pictured in South London in 2018. They have five children\n\nThe BBC was also blindsided by the criminal charges against former its former star presenter Huw Edwards, with bosses only told of the allegations a few hours before they were made public, an insider has claimed.\n\nIn April, Edwards resigned from the BBC on medical grounds and left without a payout. He then moved in with his mother in Wales.\n\nBut it has emerged that Edwards was arrested on November 8 last year and charged just over a month ago on June 26 following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\nA BBC insider reportedly said the corporation only found out Edwards was facing criminal charges hours before it was made public, according to The Times.\n\nMembers of staff were rocked by the news, which they said senior management must have been unaware of.\n\nA senior source told The Times: 'The BBC was informed by the Met Police when a call came through [on Monday].'\n\nEdwards - who helmed royal and political events at the BBC before resigning in April - has been bailed and will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court this Wednesday.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978, and if convicted he could face a maximum of up to 10 years in prison.\n\nCategory A involves images involving penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism; Category B covers images which show non-penetrative sexual activity; while Category C is for indecent images not within categories B or C.\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesman told MailOnline yesterday: 'Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation.\n\n'The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\nHuw Edwards is seen walking through London's Marylebone on June 17 last year with his ID tag\n\n'Edwards was arrested on November 8, 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, July 31.'\n\nThe resignation from the BBC by married father-of-five Edwards in April followed allegations that he paid someone for sexually explicit pictures.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police and South Wales Police both said in July last year that no criminal offence had been committed by Edwards.\n\nEdwards was absent from screens from when the story first broke in July 2023 until his exit in April 2024.\n\nHe remained on the payroll while suspended, which is normal BBC policy, and was suffering from serious mental health issues and received in-patient hospital care.\n\nThe BBC confirmed at the time of his departure that he had not received a pay-off and was leaving 'on the basis of medical advice from his doctors'.\n\nHe had long been a fixture in the coverage of major political and royal events, announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe also anchored the BBC's broadcast of the King's coronation last year.\n\nLast week the BBC confirmed Edwards was paid more than \u00a3475,000 in 2023/24 before he resigned and left.\n\nHuw Edwards will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday (file picture)\n\nThe veteran newsreader was paid between \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election specials and other television programming, according to the BBC's annual report.\n\nThis marked an increase from 2022/23, when he was paid between \u00a3435,000 and 439,999 for 180 days presenting on BBC One, as well as news specials.\n\nThroughout the years, Edwards presented the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (now the Prince and Princess of Wales) in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, in 2021.\n\nThe BBC News At {"uri": "8249225876", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "16:08:27", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T16:08:27Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T16:07:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://thetab.com/uk/2024/07/29/huw-edwards-charged-with-making-indecent-images-of-children-here-is-everything-we-know-377348", "title": "Huw Edwards charged with making indecent images of children: Here is everything we know", "body": "Former BBC presenter Huw Edwards has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children, the Metropolitan Police said.\n\nThe offences are claimed to be linked to 31 images shared on WhatsApp. Huw Edwards will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court for a hearing at 10am Wednesday morning.\n\nThe presenter was arrested last November by London's Met Police - and charged with the offences on Wednesday, June 26.\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesman said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation. The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\nMaking indecent images means downloading them. If you download an image, it \"makes\" the image on your computer. The charge for physically making the photo would be \"production of indecent images of children\".\n\nAccording to the charges, Edwards is accused of having six images of a child in the most serious category A, as well as 12 in category B and 19 in category C.Category A involves images involving penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism. Category B covers images which show non-penetrative sexual activity. Category C is for indecent images not within categories B or C. Ministry of Justice guidelines state that the definition of \"child\" is anyone under 18.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978, and if found guilty, the penalty would be a maximum of 10 years imprisonment.\n\nAfter being arrested in November and charged on Wednesday the 26th of July, Huw Edwards will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday 31st July.\n\nHuw Edwards resigned from his BBC newsreader role in April. Announcing the news in a short statement, The BBC said: \"Huw Edwards has resigned and left the BBC. After 40 years of service, Huw explained that his decision was made on the basis of advice. The BBC has accepted his resignation.\"\n\nLast week, the BBC's annual salary report revealed former News at Ten anchor Edwards was the corporation's third-highest paid star from April 2023 to March 2024. He earned between \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 in the period, whilst he was no longer working.\n\nA Crown Prosecution Service spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of South West London, has been charged with three offences of making indecent images of children. The CPS authorised the charges after a Metropolitan Police investigation. Mr Edwards will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday 31 July 2024. We remind all that proceedings are active, and the defendant has the right to a fair trial. It is extremely important that there should be no reporting, commentary, or sharing of information online which could in any way prejudice these proceedings.\"\n\n* Full statement as Huw Edwards named They have five children\n\nEdwards - who helmed royal and political events at the BBC before resigning in April - has been bailed and will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court this Wednesday.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978, and if convicted he could face a maximum of up to 10 years in prison.\n\nCategory A involves images involving penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism; Category B covers images which show non-penetrative sexual activity; while Category C is for indecent images not within categories B or C.\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesman told MailOnline yesterday: 'Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation.\n\n'The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\nHuw Edwards is seen walking through London's Marylebone on June 17 last year with his ID tag\n\n'Edwards was arrested on November 8, 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, July 31.'\n\nThe resignation from the BBC by married father-of-five Edwards in April followed allegations that he paid someone for sexually explicit pictures.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police and South Wales Police both said in July last year that no criminal offence had been committed by Edwards.\n\nEdwards was absent from screens from when the story first broke in July 2023 until his exit in April 2024.\n\nHuw Edwards helmed major royal and political events at the BBC before resigning in April\n\nHe remained on the payroll while suspended, which is normal BBC policy, and was suffering from serious mental health issues and received in-patient hospital care.\n\nThe BBC confirmed at the time of his departure that he had not received a pay-off and was leaving 'on the basis of medical advice from his doctors'.\n\nHe had long been a fixture in the coverage of major political and royal events, announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe also anchored the BBC's broadcast of the King's coronation last year.\n\nLast week the BBC confirmed Edwards was paid more than \u00a3475,000 in 2023/24 before he resigned and left.\n\nHuw Edwards will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday (file picture)\n\nThe veteran newsreader was paid between \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election specials and other television programming, according to the BBC's annual report.\n\nThis marked an increase from 2022/23, when he was paid between \u00a3435,000 and 439,999 for 180 days presenting on BBC One, as well as news specials.\n\nThroughout the years, Edwards presented the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (now the Prince and Princess of Wales) in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, in 2021.\n\nThe BBC News At Ten presenter was also the broadcaster's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance, and took over This is the first time disgraced Huw has been seen in public since July 5, 2023.\n\nThe court heard that Huw had been involved in an online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021. The adult man sent him 377 sexual images. 41 of those images were indecent images of children.\n\n36 of the indecent images of kids were sent during a two-month period. On February 2, 2021, the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards had a chilling remark in response and told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C. Of the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was age between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court was told Edwards' offending had a starting point of 12 months in prison. However, his barrister, Philip Evans KC, said there were mitigating factors and the sentence should be suspended. He told the court: \"There are serious issues in relation to Mr Edwards health, both physical and mental, at the time of the offending and now.\"\n\nOn Monday, it was announced that the BBC newsreader had been charged with making indecent images of children. More info\n\nHuw Edwards is said to have moved out of his family home and split up with his wife Vicky Flind.\n\nThe news comes after reports the former BBC News presenter has been charged with making indecent images of children. Edwards was arrested on November 8 2023 and charged on Wednesday, June 26 following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He is now due to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court tomorrow Wednesday, July 31.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp. The offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978, and if found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of six months imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine, reports the Mirror.\n\nThe former BBC News presenter has now reportedly moved out of his family home in Dulwich, south London that he stared with Vicky.\n\nHe is believed to have moved to another home in the capital and has been splitting his time between there and his native Wales.\n\nEdwards is not yet thought to have divorced from Flind, who he shares three sons and two daughters with.\n\nA source told The Sun: \"They separated quite a long time ago but have not announced it publicly. Huw has been living elsewhere for a while.\"\n\nThe pair were engaged in 1993 and are said to have met when he was 30 and working as a BBC correspondent in Westminster.\n\nHis estranged wife is two years his junior and has worked on shows including ITV's Peston and BBC One's This Week.\n\nCops confirmed on Monday that Mr Edwards has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nThe offences are alleged to have taken place between 2020 and 2022. A Metropolitan Police spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation. The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on 8 November 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July. Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nAccording to the CPS website, \"making indecent images can have a wide definition in the law and can include opening an email attachment containing such an image, downloading one from a website, or receiving one via social media, even if unsolicited and even if part of a group.\"\n\nEdwards was stripped of his role at the National Churches Trust today, Tuesday, July 30.\n\nThe charity, which supports the UK's churches to maintain their historic sites and buildings, as well as ensuring places of worship remain accessible to all, confirmed in a statement Edwards was no longer a Vice President.\n\nIt read: \"In light of the news yesterday, the National Churches Trust has confirmed that Huw Edwards is no longer a Vice President for the charity. We are shocked and saddened by the recent developments.\"\n\nUntil recently, Edwards was one of the main BBC One's Ten O'Clock News presenters and announced the death of Queen Elizabeth II in September 2022. {"uri": "8252126994", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:19:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:19:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:18:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/news/article-13692595/huw-edwards-guilty-child-pornography-charges-court-appearance.html", "title": "Huw Edwards admits child porn charges over 37 indecent images", "body": "Former BBC news star Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to making indecent images of children - and claimed the images 'were sent to him by another paedophile'.\n\nThe 62-year-old arrived at Westminster Magistrates' Court accused of three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nThe offences took place between 2020 and 2022 and relate to 37 images shared in a WhatsApp chat.\n\nEdwards - who helmed royal and political events at the BBC before resigning in April - claims the pictures were sent to him by another paedophile on the messaging app, the court heard.\n\nDressed in a navy-blue suit and wearing black sunglasses, Edwards arrived outside of court flanked by eight police officers.\n\nWith a blank expression on his face, the former BBC star refused to answer any questions as he made his way through the media melee.\n\nHuw Edwards has arrived at Westminster Magistrates' Court this morning. He faces three counts of making indecent images of children\n\nEdwards arrived at the central London court surrounded by police officers today\n\nThe former BBC News star wore a dark blue suit, tie and black shades as he walked into court\n\nThe 62-year-old star faced a media scrum as he walked into the court building this morning\n\nIf convicted, the famed former newsreader could face up to 10 years in prison (he is pictured entering court today surrounded by a police escort)\n\nFormer BBC host Huw Edwards has been charged with making indecent images of children. Friends said they had no idea he had even been arrested\n\nThere were frenzied scenes as the former news anchor was led into court, with protesters shouting as he made his way through the media scrum into the building.\n\nJournalists outside the court were seen sprinting across the road as Edwards arrived.\n\nPhotographers were knocked to the ground as they scrambled to get to the broadcaster, with one snapper's camera smashed to pieces in the melee.\n\nThe ex-News at Ten presenter was charged in June, but the details were only revealed on Monday.\n\nIf convicted, he could face a maximum jail term of 10 years.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images - the most serious child pornography images - 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978, and if convicted he could face a maximum of up to 10 years in prison.\n\nCategory A involves images involving penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism; Category B covers images which show non-penetrative sexual activity; while Category C is for indecent images not within categories B or C.\n\nThe bombshell news of the veteran broadcaster's child porn charges are said to have rocked Edwards' former colleagues.\n\nAnd it prompted questions about why it took prosecutors so long to reveal the charges Edwards is now facing.\n\nEdwards was swarmed by press and photographers in central London ahead of his first court appearance this morning\n\nEdwards faced a media frenzy as he arrived at Westminster Magistrates' Court today\n\nThe presenter did not appear to say anything to the media as he was led into the court by police\n\nEdwards wore dark sunglasses on his way into the court building this morning\n\nEdwards had a blank expression on his face as he made his way through the media melee\n\nNews of Edwards' child porn charges were revealed on Monday. He was charged with the offences in June. He is pictured arriving at court today\n\nThere were frenzied scenes outside the court house as Edwards was led into the building, surrounded by eight police officers\n\nOne former colleague and friend told MailOnline: 'Huw kept his arrest completely secret'.\n\nEdwards was not charged by the Met Police with any crime when the scandal first broke in July 2023. But he was suspended from his job at the BBC.\n\nHe remained absent from screens until his exit in April 2024.\n\nBut the news anchor remained on the payroll while suspended, which is normal BBC policy, and was suffering from serious mental health issues and received in-patient hospital care.\n\nHowever, friends say they had no idea about the alleged offences Edwards was facing, with one telling MailOnline Edwards' arrest had been kept a 'secret'.\n\n'It turns out he was arrested four months later and nobody knew. I had no idea until he was charged', the friend from the BBC said.\n\nAnother former colleague of the star said: 'It's a mess - and tragic for all concerned.'\n\nThe BBC was also blindsided by the criminal charges against its former star presenter, with bosses only told of the allegations a few hours before they were made public, an insider has claimed.\n\nA senior source told The Times: 'The BBC was informed by the Met Police when a call came through [on Monday].'\n\nEdwards has since left the family home and has reportedly split with his TV producer wife, Vicky Flind (the pair are pictured together in 2018 in London)\n\nIf Edwards is convicted, the former BBC star could face a maximum jail term of 10 years (he is pictured being escorted into Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday morning)\n\nEdwards was surrounded by photographers as he made his way into the magistrates' court\n\nThe last picture of the former BBC News star captures him crossing the threshold into the court building this morning\n\nRevealing his arrest earlier this week, a Metropolitan Police spokesman said: 'Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation.\n\n'The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n'Edwards was arrested on 8 November 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\n'He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July.'\n\nLast night a former attorney general said it was 'very puzzling' that the Crown Prosecution Service did not publish the details of the charges brought against Edwards around the time he was charged.\n\nHe added that the CPS's actions did not seem 'in accordance with' the principles of open justice, The Telegraph first reported.\n\nFollowing the allegations, Edwards moved back in with his mother in Wales.\n\nHe has reportedly since split with his TV producer wife Vicky Flind, who he got engaged to in 1993. The couple share three sons and two daughters.\n\nPictured are members of the press waiting outside Westminster Magistrates' Court today ahead of the former BBC star's arrival\n\nOne female police officer appeared to shout at the crowd as Edwards made his way into the court on Wednesday\n\nEdwards had long been a fixture in the coverage of major political and royal events, announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe also anchored the BBC's broadcast of the King's coronation last year.\n\nLast week the BBC confirmed Edwards was paid more than \u00a3475,000 in 2023/24 before he resigned and left.\n\nThe veteran newsreader was paid between \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election specials and other television programming, according to the BBC's annual report.\n\nThis marked an increase from 2022/23, when he was paid between \u00a3435,000 and 439,999 for 180 days presenting on BBC One, as well as news specials.\n\nThroughout the years, Edwards presented the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (now the Prince and Princess of Wales) in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, in 2021.\n\nThe BBC News At Ten presenter was also the broadcaster's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance, and took over election coverage from the long-serving David Dimbleby in 2019.", "source": {"uri": This news follows reports that Edwards has been charged with creating indecent images of children.\n\nThe ex-BBC star was arrested on 8th November 2023 and subsequently charged on Wednesday, June 26, after authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service, reports the Mirror.\n\nThe charge sheet alleges that Edwards had six category A images, 12 category B pictures, and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp. These offences are in violation of sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978.\n\nJoin us on WhatsApp to get the latest news straight to your phone\n\nIf convicted, he could face a maximum penalty of six months imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine. Reports suggest that Edwards has now left his family home in Dulwich, south London, which he shared with Vicky. He is believed to have relocated to another property in London and has been dividing his time between there and his native Wales.\n\nEdwards is due to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday. It's understood that he has yet to finalise his divorce from Flind, with whom he shares five children. An insider revealed to The Sun: \"They separated quite a long time ago but have not announced it publicly. Huw has been living elsewhere for a while.\"\n\nEdwards and Ms Flind became engaged in 1993 after meeting when he was a BBC correspondent in Westminster at the age of 30. Ms Flind, two years his junior, has worked on shows such as ITV's Peston and BBC One's This Week.\n\nOn Monday, the Metropolitan Police confirmed that Edwards has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children. The alleged offences are said to have occurred between 2020 and 2022.\n\nA spokesperson for the Metropolitan Police stated: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation. The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\"\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on 8 November 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July. Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nThe Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) explains on its website that \"making indecent images can have a wide definition in the law and can include opening an email attachment containing such an image, downloading one from a website, or receiving one via social media, even if unsolicited and even if part of a group.\"\n\nFollowing recent events, the National Churches Trust has announced on Tuesday that Huw Edwards has been removed from his position as Vice President. The charity, dedicated to the preservation of the UK's historic church buildings and ensuring they remain accessible, released a statement saying: \"In light of the news yesterday, the National Churches Trust has confirmed that Huw Edwards is no longer a Vice President for the charity. {"uri": "8249333804", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "17:32:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T17:32:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T17:31:18Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/29/bbc-star-news-anchor-huw-edwards-charged-over-indecent-images-of-kids/", "title": "BBC Star News Anchor Huw Edwards Charged Over 'Indecent' Images of Kids", "body": "Huw Edwards, the veteran lead anchor of BBC News, will appear in a London court Wednesday after being charged with three counts of making 37 indecent images of children.\n\nPolice say the offenses took place between December 2020 and April 2022, and \"relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\"\n\nThe Sun reported that Edwards is accused of having six category A images, the most serious classification of indecent images, on a phone. He is also accused of making 12 Category B pictures and 19 Category C photographs. If found guilty, he faces up to 10 years in jail.\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation. The offenses, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat. Edwards was arrested on November 8, 2023.\n\n\"He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorization from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July. Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nEdwards, 62, who hosted the main 10 p.m. news bulletin and led the BBC's coverage of major events such as the funerals of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, was one of the BBC's highest-paid presenters.\n\nHe has not appeared on TV since last July when allegations first surfaced that he'd paid a teenager for sexually explicit images. His name was eventually revealed after a period of frenzied speculation about the identity of the \"BBC presenter\" concerned. At that time, London's Metropolitan Police and South Wales Police said that no criminal offense had been committed by the star.\n\nEdwards was the BBC's third-highest-paid star from April 2023 to March 2024, earning between \u00a3475,000 ($610,000) and \u00a3479,999 ($616,000) in the period.\n\nLast July, in naming her husband as the star behind the claims, Edwards' wife, Vicky Flind, said: \"In light of the recent reporting regarding the 'BBC Presenter' I am making this statement on behalf of my husband Huw Edwards, after what have been five extremely difficult days for our family. I am doing this primarily out of concern for his mental well-being and to protect our children.\n\n\"Huw is suffering from serious mental health issues. As is well documented, he has been treated for severe depression in recent years. The events of the last few days have greatly worsened matters, he has suffered another serious episode and is now receiving in-patient hospital care where he'll stay for the foreseeable future.\n\n\"Once well enough to do so, he intends to respond to the stories that have been published. To be clear Huw was first told that there were allegations being made against him last Thursday. In the circumstances and given Huw's condition I would like to ask that the privacy of my family and everyone else caught up in these upsetting events is respected. I know that Huw is deeply sorry that so many colleagues have been impacted by the recent media speculation. We hope this statement will bring that to an end.\"\n\nIn April 2024, Edwards resigned. \"Huw Edwards has today resigned and left the BBC,\" a BBC spokesman said at the time. \"After 40 years of service, Huw has explained that his decision was made on the basis of medical advice from his doctors.\" The spokesperson said Edwards' resignation \"will allow all parties to move forward.\"", He is also accused of making 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs. If found guilty, he faces up to 10 years in jail.\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation. The offenses, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat. Edwards was arrested on November 8 2023.\n\n\"He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorization from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July. Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nEdwards, 62, who hosted the main 10 p.m. news bulletin and led the BBC's coverage of major events such as the funerals of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, was one of the BBC's highest-paid presenters.\n\nHe has not appeared on TV since last July, when allegations first surfaced that he'd paid a teenager for sexually explicit images. His name was eventually revealed after a period of frenzied speculation about the identity of the \"BBC presenter\" concerned. At that time, London's Metropolitan Police and South Wales Police said that no criminal offense had been committed by the star.\n\nEdwards was the BBC third-highest paid star from April 2023 to March 2024, earning between \u00a3475,000 ($610,000) and \u00a3479,999 ($616,000) in the period.\n\nLast July, in naming her husband as the star behind the claims, Edwards' wife, Vicky Flind, said: \"In light of the recent reporting regarding the 'BBC Presenter' I am making this statement on behalf of my husband Huw Edwards, after what have been five extremely difficult days for our family. I am doing this primarily out of concern for his mental well-being and to protect our children.\n\n\"Huw is suffering from serious mental health issues. As is well documented, he has been treated for severe depression in recent years. The events of the last few days have greatly worsened matters, he has suffered another serious episode and is now receiving in-patient hospital care where he'll stay for the foreseeable future.\n\n\"Once well enough to do so, he intends to respond to the stories that have been published. To be clear Huw was first told that there were allegations being made against him last Thursday. In the circumstances and given Huw's condition I would like to ask that the privacy of my family and everyone else caught up in these upsetting events is respected. I know that Huw is deeply sorry that so many colleagues have been impacted by the recent media speculation. We hope this statement will bring that to an end.\"\n\nIn April 2024, Edwards resigned. \"Huw Edwards has today resigned and left the BBC,\" a BBC spokesman said at the time. \"After 40 years of Friends said they had no idea he had even been arrested\n\nPictured are members of the press waiting outside Westminster Magistrates' Court today ahead of the former BBC star's arrival\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images - the most serious child pornography images - 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978, and if convicted he could face a maximum of up to 10 years in prison.\n\nCategory A involves images involving penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism; Category B covers images which show non-penetrative sexual activity; while Category C is for indecent images not within categories B or C.\n\nThe bombshell news of the veteran broadcaster's child porn charges are said to have rocked Edwards' former colleagues.\n\nAnd it prompted questions about why it took prosecutors so long to reveal the charges Edwards is now facing.\n\nOne former colleague and friend told MailOnline: 'Huw kept his arrest completely secret'.\n\nEdwards was not charged by the Met Police with any crime when the scandal first broke in July 2023. But he was suspended from his job at the BBC.\n\nHe remained absent from screens until his exit in April 2024.\n\nEdwards has since left the family home and has reportedly split with his TV producer wife, Vicky Flind (the pair are pictured together in 2018 in London)\n\nBut the news anchor remained on the payroll while suspended, which is normal BBC policy, and was suffering from serious mental health issues and received in-patient hospital care.\n\nHowever, friends say they had no idea about the alleged offences Edwards was facing, with one telling MailOnline Edwards' arrest had been kept a 'secret'.\n\n'It turns out he was arrested four months later and nobody knew. I had no idea until he was charged', the friend from the BBC said.\n\nAnother former colleague of the star said: 'It's a mess - and tragic for all concerned.'\n\nThe BBC was also blindsided by the criminal charges against its former star presenter, with bosses only told of the allegations a few hours before they were made public, an insider has claimed.\n\nA senior source told The Times: 'The BBC was informed by the Met Police when a call came through [on Monday].'\n\nLast night a former attorney general said it was 'very puzzling' that the Crown Prosecution Service did not publish the details of the charges brought against Edwards around the time he was charged.\n\nHe added that the CPS's actions did not seem 'in accordance with' the principles of open justice, The Telegraph first reported.\n\nFollowing the allegations, Edwards moved back in with his mother in Wales.\n\nHe has reportedly since split with his TV producer wife Vicky Flind, who he got engaged to in 1993. The couple share three sons and two daughters.\n\nEdwards had long been a fixture in the coverage of major political and royal events, announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHuw Edwards will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday (file picture)\n\nHe also anchored the BBC's broadcast of the King's coronation last year.\n\nLast week the BBC confirmed Edwards was paid more than \u00a3475,000 in 2023/24 before he resigned and left.\n\nThe veteran newsreader was paid between \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election specials and other television programming, according to the BBC's annual report.\n\nThis marked an increase from 2022/23, when he was paid between \u00a3435,000 and 439,999 for 180 days presenting on BBC One, as well as news specials.\n\nThroughout the years, Edwards presented the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (now the Prince and Princess of Wales) in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, in 2021.\n\nThe BBC News At Ten presenter was also the broadcaster's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance, and took over election coverage from the long-serving He is also accused of making 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs. If found guilty, he faces up to 10 years in jail.\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation. The offenses, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat. Edwards was arrested on November 8 2023.\n\n\"He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorization from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July. Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nBBC Star Embroiled in Alleged Sex Pics Scandal Resigns\n\nEdwards, 62, who hosted the main 10 p.m. news bulletin and led the BBC's coverage of major events such as the funerals of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip, was one of the BBC's highest-paid presenters.\n\nHe has not appeared on TV since last July, when allegations first surfaced that he'd paid a teenager for sexually explicit images. His name was eventually revealed after a period of frenzied speculation about the identity of the \"BBC presenter\" concerned. At that time, London's Metropolitan Police and South Wales Police said that no criminal offense had been committed by the star.\n\nEdwards was the BBC third-highest paid star from April 2023 to March 2024, earning between \u00a3475,000 ($610,000) and \u00a3479,999 ($616,000) in the period.\n\nLast July, in naming her husband as the star behind the claims, Edwards' wife, Vicky Flind, said: \"In light of the recent reporting regarding the 'BBC Presenter' I am making this statement on behalf of my husband Huw Edwards, after what have been five extremely difficult days for our family. I am doing this primarily out of concern for his mental well-being and to protect our children.\n\n\"Huw is suffering from serious mental health issues. As is well documented, he has been treated for severe depression in recent years. The events of the last few days have greatly worsened matters, he has suffered another serious episode and is now receiving in-patient hospital care where he'll stay for the foreseeable future.\n\n\"Once well enough to do so, he intends to respond to the stories that have been published. To be clear Huw was first told that there were allegations being made against him last Thursday. In the circumstances and given Huw's condition I would like to ask that the privacy of my family and everyone else caught up in these upsetting events is respected. I know that Huw is deeply sorry that so many colleagues have been impacted by the recent media speculation. We hope this statement will bring that to an end.\"\n\nIn April 2024, Edwards resigned. \"Huw Edwards has today resigned and left the BBC,\" a BBC spokesman said at the time. \"After 40 years of service, Huw has explained that his decision was made on the basis of medical advice from his doctors.\" The spokesperson said Edwards' resignation \"will allow all parties to move forward.\"\n\nRead more at The Daily Beast.\n\nGet the Daily Beast's biggest scoops and scandals delivered right to your inbox. {"uri": "8252204704", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:06:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:06:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:06:05Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.the-sun.com/news/12066676/huw-edwards-admits-sexual-images-children-whatsapp/", "title": "Huw Edwards admits being sent sexual image of boy aged between 7 and 9 by paedo", "body": "HUW Edwards has admitted being sent a string of indecent photos of children - including a \"moving image\" of a boy as young as seven.\n\nThe former BBC presenter, 62, received the pictures on WhatsApp between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nEdwards, 62, today pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court was told seven of the 41 images fall under Category A - the most serious classification.\n\nThis included two moving images of younger children, possibly aged seven and nine years old, as well as kids aged between 13 and 15.\n\nA further 12 images were classed as Category B and 19 as Category C.\n\nThe ex-presenter could face a maximum of ten years in prison when he is sentenced on September 16.\n\nProsecutor Ian Hope stressed Edwards had not created any of the images himself.\n\nHe said the newsreader was involved in an online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nDuring this time, the man sent Edwards 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nWhen he sent the film featuring the young boy, Edwards was told he was quite young looking and there were more illegal images.\n\nEdwards then told the man on several occasions not to send him anything against the law.\n\nNo more of these pictures or video were sent and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nEdwards' barrister Philip Evans KC told the court there was no suggestion the ex-newsreader had made or created any of the images.\n\nHe also said no indecent images had been found on any of Edward's' own devices and he had not looked for any such material from anyone else.\n\nThe lawyer added: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nThe veteran broadcaster was arrested in November and charged on June 26 - although the information has only just been released.\n\nThe CPS has defended its decision to reveal the information on Monday ahead of his first court appearance - despite a lawyer describing the move as \"puzzling\".\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesman said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation.\n\n\"The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on 8 November 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\n\"He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July.\"\n\nEdwards quit the BBC in April after 40 years reporting on some of the world's biggest stories.\n\nThis included leading coverage of the Queen's funeral and Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding.\n\nHe was one of the BBC's highest-profile and highest-paid presenters with a pay bracket between \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24.\n\nThe Sun revealed yesterday how the dad-of-five has split from his TV producer wife.\n\nEdwards has moved out of the family home in Dulwich, South London, he shared with Vicky.\n\nThe couple, who got engaged in 1993, have three sons and two He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\n\"He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July.\n\n\"Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case.\n\n\"Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nThe offences can carry a jail term of up to 10 years.\n\nMinistry of Justice guidelines states that the definition of 'child' is anyone under 18.\n\nMarried dad-of-five Edwards resigned from the BBC three months ago after a glittering career spanning almost 40 years.\n\nThe Corporation revealed their star presenter's resignation in a short statement on April 22.\n\nIt said: \"Huw Edwards has resigned and left the BBC.\n\n\"After 40 years of service, Huw explained that his decision was made on the basis of advice. The BBC has accepted his resignation.\"\n\nLast week, the BBC's annual salary report revealed former News at Ten anchor Edwards was the corporation's third-highest paid star from April 2023 to March 2024.\n\nHe earned between \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 in the period - with his salary only topped by Gary Lineker and Zoe Ball.\n\nWelshman Edwards was born in Bridgend in 1961 and raised in a village near Llanelli by his father, Hywel - a professor of Welsh literature and teacher mother Aerona.\n\nAfter a stint on radio in Swansea, he joined the BBC as a news trainee in 1984 before becoming Parliamentary Correspondent for BBC Wales two years later.\n\nEdwards fronted the Six O'Clock News from 1994 to 2003.\n\nAnd in January 2003, he became the main presenter of BBC One's Ten O'Clock News.\n\nAs one of the most experienced - and respected - broadcasters at the Corporation, he was trusted with state events as well as the Beeb's election coverage.\n\nThe award-winning presenter led the BBC's coverage of the funerals of Queen Elizabeth II and Prince Philip.\n\nEdwards - formerly the corporation's best-paid news reporter - was also the BBC's lead presenter at King Charles' Coronation at Westminster Abbey last May.\n\nMore than 13 million watched on BBC One as Edwards talked the nation through the ceremony which saw both Charles and Queen Camilla crowned.\n\nEdwards also hosted the May 2018 wedding of Prince Harry and Meghan in Windsor for the BBC.\n\nA Crown Prosecution Service spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of South West London, has been charged with three offences of making indecent images of children.\n\n\"The CPS authorised the charges after a Metropolitan Police investigation.\n\n\"Mr Edwards will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday 31 July 2024.\n\n\"We remind all that proceedings are active, and the defendant has the right to a fair trial.\n\n\"It is extremely important that there should be no "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/ex-bbc-presenter-huw-edwards-101407380.html", "title": "Ex-BBC presenter Huw Edwards admits having indecent images of children", "body": "Ex-BBC presenter Huw Edwards admits having indecent images of children\n\nJosh Payne, Luke O'Reilly and Margaret Davis, PA\n\n31 July 2024 at 0:17 pm\n\nFormer BBC presenter Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to making indecent images of children.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster admitted having 41 on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nWearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, the 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday.\n\nAfter entering his pleas, Edwards sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards, and adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Edwards told him not to send any under-age images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young-looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nSpeaking in Edwards' defence, his barrister, Philip Evans KC, said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nEdwards was bailed and will next appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\n\"He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July.\"\n\nEdwards quit the BBC in April after 40 years reporting on some of the world's biggest stories.\n\nThis included leading coverage of the Queen's funeral and Prince Harry and Meghan Markle's wedding.\n\nHe was The former BBC broadcaster appeared at Westminster Magistrates' Court today.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard. The indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told. The final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal. Edwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022. Edwards will be sentenced at Westminster Magistrates' Court on September 16.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court was told Edwards' offending had a starting point of 12 months in prison. However his barrister, Philip Evans KC, said there were mitigating factors and the sentence should be suspended. He said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices. It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\" He added: \"There are serious issues in relation to Mr Edwards health, both physical and mental, at the time of the offending and now.\" Edwards was bailed for I wouldn't go into specifics but in terms of the increase of pay, prior to any breaking of any story, our pay progress is under inflation but people on the list would be getting pay rises and that is fairly normally business.\"\n\nOn 22 April, the BBC announced that Huw Edwards had stepped down from his role following medical advice. \"Huw Edwards has today resigned and left the BBC,\" the broadcaster's brief statement read: \"After 40 years of service, Huw has explained that his decision was made on the basis of medical advice from his doctors. {"uri": "8252259968", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:39:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:39:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:38:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/news/uk-news/children-young-seven-indecent-images-29648438", "title": "Children as young as seven in indecent images on Huw Edwards' Whatsapp", "body": "Some of the indecent images found on Huw Edwards' Whatsapp were of children as young as seven, a court heard.\n\nThe former BBC presenter pleaded guilty to making indecent images of children at Westminster Magistrates' Court this morning (July 31). The veteran broadcaster admitted to having 41 of the images on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nThe court was told how Edwards had seven category A images on his WhatsApp - the most severe. The estimated age of most of the children in these pictures was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nREAD NEXT: LIVE: Huw Edwards pleads guilty to making indecent images of children\n\nHe had 12 category B images and 22 category C. The final indecent image was sent to Edwards in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe court heard how the presenter had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images. 41 of these were the indecent images of children.\n\nAs the final category A film was sent, the man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal. Edwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court heard.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022. Edwards appeared at court today wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses.\n\nThe 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday. After entering his pleas, Edwards sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards, and adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nSpeaking in Edwards' defence, his barrister Philip Evans KC said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort. It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat. Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nEdwards was bailed. They are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022,\n\nPolice added in their statement that Edwards \"has been bailed\" and will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, July 31.\n\n\"Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case,\" police concluded, warning, \"Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nPer the BBC, Edwards has been accused of having six category A images on a phone, as well as 12 category B photos and 19 category C pictures.\n\nThe Crown Prosecution Service declined to comment on the image categories when contacted by PEOPLE, stating that \"any details on alleged offending will be discussed in court.\"\n\nEdwards, who is the father of five children, was born in Bridgend, Wales, and spent almost all his professional life at the BBC. He was at the helm as the BBC announced the death of Queen Elizabeth on Sept. 8, 2022, would regularly host U.K. general election coverage and was also called upon to anchor the organization's coverage of the late monarch's funeral and King Charles' coronation in May 2023.\n\nHe left the broadcaster in April on medical grounds.\n\n\"Huw Edwards has today resigned and left the BBC,\" the BBC said in a statement on April 22. \"After 40 years of service, Huw has explained that his decision was made on the basis of medical advice from his doctors. The BBC has accepted his resignation which it believes will allow all parties to move forward. We don't believe it appropriate to comment further.\"\n\nWant to keep up with the latest crime coverage? Most notably, Britain's notorious pedophile Jimmy Savile worked for the BBC for decades, and the corporation decided to cover up his crimes while he was still actively abusing children.\n\nEdwards, the 62-year-old BBC veteran, is facing three charges of making indecent images of children between December 2020 and April 2022 after he shared them on a WhatsApp group.\n\nPolice announced Edwards was arrested on November 8 last year and charged just over a month ago on June 26 following authorization from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\nEdwards, the highest paid presenter in BBC history, presented royal and political events at the BBC before resigning in April. He has been released on bail and will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court this Wednesday.\n\nDaily Mail report: According to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978, and if convicted he could face a maximum of up to 10 years in prison.\n\nCategory A involves images involving penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism; Category B covers images which show non-penetrative sexual activity; while Category C is for indecent images not within categories B or C.\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesman told MailOnline today: 'Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation.\n\n'The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n'Edwards was arrested on November 8, 2023. children.\n\nInterrupting coverage of Chancellor Rachel Reeves' statement in the House of Commons, the BBC announced the breaking news.\n\nEntertainment correspondent Lizo Mzimba said: \"The former BBC presenter Huw Edwards has been charged with three offences of making indecent images of children.\n\n\"That's according to statements from the Metropolitan Police and from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\n\"The Metropolitan Police said that the CPS authorised the charges after a Metropolitan Police investigation.\n\nEntertainment correspondent Lizo Mzimba announced the breaking news that Huw Edwards has been charged with possessing indecent images of children\n\n\"They said Mr Edwards will appear at Westminster Magistrates Court this Wednesdays, July 31, 2024.\n\n\"A little more detail from the Crown Prosecution Service: they say the offences are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022 and relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"They say Huw Edwards was arrested on November 8, 2023, he was charged on Wednesday, June 26 following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\n\"Huw Edwards, the former BBC presenter, of course for a long time one of the most prominent faces on the BBC, presenting generally election coverage, big royal occasions, big state occasions, for many people one of the best known and most important faces of the cooperation and also one of its highest paid names.\"\n\nAfter the breaking news was reported, BBC News returned to coverage of the Chancellor of the Exchequer's statement in Parliament.\n\nEdwards, 62, has been charged with child pornography offences after 37 indecent images were allegedly shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\nThe former broadcaster, who resigned in April, has been bailed ahead of his appearance in court on Wednesday.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, he is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978, and if found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years' imprisonment.\n\nBBC News cut away from coverage of Rachel Reeves' statement to inform viewers of the news\n\nHuw Edwards, 62, has been charged with child pornography offences after 37 indecent images were allegedly shared on a WhatsApp chat\n\nCategory A involves images involving penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism; Category B covers images which show non-penetrative sexual activity; while Category C is for indecent images not within categories B or C.\n\nThe resignation from the BBC by married father-of-five Edwards in April followed allegations that he paid someone for sexually explicit pictures.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police and South Wales Police both said in July last year that no criminal offence had been committed by Edwards.\n\nEdwards was absent from screens from when the story first broke in July 2023 until his exit in April 2024.\n\nHe remained on the payroll while suspended, which is normal BBC policy, and was suffering from serious mental health issues and received in-patient hospital care.\n\nThe BBC confirmed at the time of his departure that he had not received a pay-off and was leaving 'on the basis of medical advice from his doctors'.\n\nLast week Edwards Charged With Making Indecent Images of Children", "body": "Former BBC presenter Huw Edwards has been charged with making indecent images of children, police said on Monday.\n\nThe 62-year-old newsreader, who left the corporation in April, faces three charges over alleged criminal activity which took place between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, the Welsh journalist is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures, and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nHe is due in Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday and, if found guilty, could receive a penalty of up to 10 years' imprisonment.\n\nMr. Edwards was one of the the most recognisable faces on British TV having presented the BBC \"News at Ten\" for two decades.\n\nThe journalist announced the death of the late Queen Elizabeth II to the nation on the BBC as well as presiding over her funeral for the corporation.\n\nHe also fronted the broadcast of her successor, King Charles's coronation last year, as well as the weddings of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (now the Prince and Princess of Wales) in 2011, the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, in 2021.\n\nBefore he formally stepped down earlier this year, he was the BBC's highest-paid newsreader, earning somewhere between \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023 to 2024.\n\nDuring that time he spent 160 days on air, according to the BBC's latest annual report.\n\nA Metropolitan Police spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of
