type.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy, with the man telling the newsreader the child was \"quite young looking\" and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nFormer BBC broadcaster Huw Edwards arriving at Westminster Magistrates\u00b4 Court on Wednesday (Jonathan Brady/PA)\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told in a 26-minute hearing.\n\nHe appeared nervous, fidgeting with his hands as Chief Magistrate Paul Goldspring told him he would not be sentencing him on Wednesday.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021, the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, to which Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nNo more indecent images more were sent after August 2021, but the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nSpeaking in Edwards' defence, his barrister Philip Evans KC said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nMr Evans said the defendant had \"both mental and physical\" health issues.\n\nHe told the court: \"It is obvious to the court, I'm sure, that Mr Edwards was not just of good character, but of exceptional character.\"\n\nThe broadcaster was emotionless as he pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nAfter admitting the charges, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards.\n\nHe adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nVeteran broadcaster Huw Edwards appeared at Westminster Magistrates\u00b4 Court on Wednesday (Aaron Chown/PA)\n\nMr Hope told the court that a suspended sentence might be considered for Edwards.\n\nSetting out the potential penalties under the law, he said that where there is the prospect of rehabilitation a community order and sexual offender treatment programme could be considered as alternatives to a custodial sentence.\n\nSentencing guidelines set the starting point for any jail term for possession of a Category A image at 12 months, with a range of 26 weeks to three years.\n\nThe starting point is 26 weeks for a category B image, and a community order for category C, he said.\n\nAggravating features to be taken into account for Edwards include that the images included moving images, and the young age of the child thought to be seven to nine years old in two of the category A images.\n\nMitigating factors are Edwards' early guilty plea, his previous good character, his mental health issues and what Mr Hope said is \"genuine remorse\".\n\nHe faced a barrage of cameras and photographers as he left court, but made no comment as he departed in a black Mercedes with tinted windows.\n\nClaire Brinton, from the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS), said: \"Accessing indecent images of underage people perpetuates the sexual exploitation of children, which has deep, long-lasting trauma on these victims.\n\n\"The CPS and the Metropolitan Police were able to prove that Edwards was receiving illegal material involving children via WhatsApp.\n\n\"This prosecution sends a clear message that the CPS, working alongside with the police, will work to bring to justice those who seek to exploit children, wherever that abuse takes place.\"\n\nEdwards will be appear at the same court again on September 16.", "source": {"uri": 37 photographs on WhatsApp, including six of the most serious type.\n\nEdwards arrived at Westminster Magistrates' Court shortly before 9.15am on Wednesday wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police said he was arrested in November last year and charged on June 26.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp - offences contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978.\n\nThe images are alleged to have been shared via WhatsApp.\n\nIf found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison.\n\nEdwards was one of the BBC's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors before he left the corporation in He resigned in April.\n\nHe has been charged with three counts of making an indecent photograph or pseudo-photograph of a child relating to images found on a child's phone, according to court documents.\n\n\"The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat,\" a London police spokesperson said.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on 8 November, 2023. Edwards said: \"Guilty.\"\n\nJudge Paul Goldspring said Edwards would be sentenced on Sept. 16. The maximum penalty for the offences is 10 years in prison.\n\nDuring the 25-minute hearing, prosecutor Ian Hope said the 41 still or moving indecent images had been sent to Edwards by an adult male on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nHope added that seven of the 41 images were of the most serious kind and that two of that seven were pornographic videos of a child possibly aged between seven and nine years old.\n\nEdwards' lawyer Philip Evans emphasized that the charges to which his client had indicated guilty pleas related only to unsolicited images that were sent to him via WhatsApp. He said Edwards neither kept nor sent any images.\n\n\"There is no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has in any way made, in the traditional sense of the word, any images in any physical way or created any images of any sort,\" Evans said.\n\nEdwards joined BBC in the 1980s. distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards, and adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nVeteran broadcaster Huw Edwards appeared at Westminster Magistrates\u00b4 Court on Wednesday (Aaron Chown/PA)\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards leaves Westminster Magistrates\u00b4 Court after the hearing (Aaron Chown/PA)\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nSpeaking in Edwards' defence, his barrister Philip Evans KC said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nEdwards was bailed and will be sentenced at Westminster Magistrates' Court on September 16.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "8252193393", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:01:06", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:01:06Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:59:38Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7411764860153198, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3036703-scandal-surrounds-former-bbc-anchor-huw-edwards", "title": "Scandal Surrounds Former BBC Anchor Huw Edwards | Politics", "body": "Former BBC presenter Huw Edwards pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent pictures of children. Edwards, known for high-profile broadcasts, faces sentencing on September 16. The charges relate to images sent to him via WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021. He resigned in April after prior allegations.\n\nFormer BBC TV news presenter Huw Edwards, a household name in Britain, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to three counts of making indecent pictures of children. Edwards, 62, who was the BBC's highest paid journalist and top news anchor until he quit in April, had arrived at London's Westminster Magistrates' Court wearing sunglasses through a throng of photographers and camera crews.\n\nAfter confirming his identity, he was asked if he wished to indicate a plea to the three charges, which relate to three different categories of indecent images. Edwards said: 'Guilty'. Judge Paul Goldspring said Edwards would be sentenced on Sept. 16.\n\nDuring the 25-minute hearing, prosecutor Ian Hope said the 41 still or moving images had been sent to Edwards by an adult male on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021. Hope added that seven of the 41 images were of the most serious kind and that two of that seven were pornographic videos of a child possibly aged seven and nine years old.\n\nEdwards' lawyer Philip Evans emphasised that the charges to which his client had indicated guilty pleas related only to images that were sent to him via WhatsApp. 'There is no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has in any way made, in the traditional sense of the word, any images in any physical way or created any images of any sort,' Evans said.\n\nEdwards, who announced the death of Queen Elizabeth to the nation in 2022 and led coverage of elections, royal weddings and the 2012 Olympics, has not been on TV screens for a year and the court appearance was his first in public since then. Edwards' offences carry a jail term of up to 10 years.\n\nEdwards, who was one of the British broadcaster's top-paid presenters last year, officially resigned from the corporation in April.\n\nThis came almost a year after reports claimed that the newsreader had paid a young person thousands of pounds for sexually explicit images. Huw, 62, and wife Vicky, 60, live in a house in Dulwich, south London, but court documents reveal he is now dividing his time between a new home in Wandsworth, south west London, and one in Wales.\n\nOK! has contacted Huw's rep for comment.\n\nVicky is a TV producer who has worked on shows including Peston on ITV and the BBC current affairs series This Week. The couple met when Huw was a BBC correspondent in Westminster, and they got engaged in 1993. They have three sons and two daughters.\n\nOn Monday 29 July, Huw Edwards was charged with making indecent images of children, following a police investigation. He was charged on Wednesday, June 26, following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, July 31. Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nHuw was best known as one of the BBC's most established news readers, and was a regular presenter of their flagship Ten O'Clock News. He covered many major political events and also announced the death of Queen Elizabeth II in September 2022 and covered the funerals of both the Queen and Prince Philip as well as the coronation of Charles III and Camilla.\n\nThe BBC confirmed in April that Huw was no longer working for them, after it was announced that he had resigned following claims of alleged misconduct. The BBC released a statement at the time which read: \"Huw Edwards has today resigned and left the BBC. After 40 years of service, Huw has explained that his decision was made on the basis of medical advice from his doctors. More info\n\nBBC presenter Huw Edwards has entered guilty pleas at Westminster Magistrates' Court to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nEdwards, 62, admitted making indecent images of children between December 2020 and April 2022. The broadcaster admitted having 37 photographs on WhatsApp, including six category A images, 12 category B and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nHuw was emotionless as he pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children. After admitting the charges at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday (July 31), he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards. He adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him to the chief magistrate Paul Goldspring.\n\nREAD MORE: Former BBC News presenter Huw Edwards seen for first time in over year as he arrives in court\n\nHe arrived at court shortly before 9.15am on Wednesday morning in a dark suit with a blue tie and sunglasses, but refused to answer questions outside. Crowds were stood outside with signs regarding child abuse as they protested while Edwards entered the building, reports The Express.\n\nNews of Edwards' charges emerged earlier this week with the Metropolitan Police stating he was arrested in November last year and charged on June 26. The charge can carry a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison.\n\nUp until April 2024, the broadcaster worked for the BBC as the most high-profile news anchor and fronted multiple major events including the King's Coronation and Queen Elizabeth II's funeral. He resigned earlier this year after 40 years of work and stated the decision was made on the basis of medical advice from his doctors.\n\nGet all the latest and breaking news in Yorkshire by signing {"uri": "2024-07-437320722", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "15:53:32", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T15:53:32Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T15:41:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/former-bbc-presenter-huw-edwards-150816319.html", "title": "Former BBC presenter Huw Edwards charged with making indecent images of children", "body": "Former BBC presenter Huw Edwards charged with making indecent images of children\n\nLaura Harding and Naomi Clarke, PA reporters\n\n29 July 2024 at 4:41 pm\n\nFormer BBC presenter Huw Edwards has been charged with making indecent images of children, the Metropolitan Police said.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster, 62, who left the corporation in April, faces three charges over alleged activity between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nHe is due in court on Wednesday.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978, and if found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years' imprisonment.\n\nA police spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London, has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation.\n\n\"The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on November 8 2023. He was charged on Wednesday June 26 following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\n\"He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday July 31.\n\n\"Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case.\n\n\"Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nEdwards was one of the BBC's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors before he left the corporation earlier this year.\n\nDuring his career, he fronted BBC's News At Ten for 20 years and anchored coverage of major national events including announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe also helmed the BBC's broadcast of the King's coronation last year.\n\nThroughout the years he presented the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (now the Prince and Princess of Wales) in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, in 2021.\n\nThe BBC News At Ten presenter was also the broadcaster's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance, and took over election coverage from the long-serving David Dimbleby in 2019.\n\nBefore he stepped down, he was the BBC's highest-paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election specials and other television programming, according to the BBC's latest annual 'We started talking then and haven't ever really stopped.'\n\nThe couple have five children together - three sons named Dan, Sammy and Amos, and two daughters, Hannah and Rebecca.\n\nOn July 29, the Met Police spokesperson said in a statement: 'Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation.\n\n'The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n'Edwards was arrested on November 8, 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, June 26 following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.'\n\nThe statement confirmed Edwards' court appearance this week, stating that he has been released on bail.\n\n'Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case.\n\n'Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.'\n\nA Crown Prosecution Service spokesperson echoed the Met's statement, adding: 'We remind all that proceedings are active, and the defendant has the right to a fair trial.\n\n'It is extremely important that there should be no reporting, commentary, or sharing of information online which could in any way prejudice these proceedings.'\n\nThe offences can carry a jail term of up to 10 years.\n\nEdwards joined the BBC as a trainee in 1984 and went on to become one of the corporation's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors, having famously broke the news of Queen Elizabeth II's death in September, 2022.\n\nMetro.co.uk has contacted a representative of Huw Edwards for comment.\n\nIf you've got a celebrity story, video or pictures get in touch with the Metro.co.uk entertainment team by {"uri": "8252267140", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:43:13", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:43:13Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:42:24Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.729411780834198, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/huw-edwards-bizarre-defence-plea-33365269", "title": "Huw Edwards' bizarre defence plea of 'exceptional character' in child porn case", "body": "Huw Edwards' barrister Philip Evans KC said the disgraced BBC broadcaster had \"both mental and physical\" health issues and was of \"exceptional character\" before he pleaded guilty to all the child pornography charges made against him.\n\nThe ex-BBC presenter, 62, was sent 41 indecent images of children. Seven of images, which were shared on WhatsApp, fall under Category A - the most serious classification. The court was told that two of the images showed a child believed to be aged between \"seven and nine\".\n\nEdwards appeared at Westminster Magistrates' Court today - the first time he has been seen in over a year since stepping down from his BBC role. Wearing a dark suit and a cobalt tie, he was flanked by police officers as he made his way into the court building amid a protest from the public. Ian Hope, prosecuting, has asked for Edwards' address to be \"restricted\" because of the \"protests\" outside court. He said it was a \"very volatile situation\".\n\nHe appeared emotionless as he pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children. After admitting the charges at Westminster Magistrates' Court, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards.\n\nThe court heard Edwards' barrister Philip Evans KC say that the broadcaster had \"both mental and physical\" health issues before he pleaded guilty. The barrister told the court: \"It is obvious to the court, I'm sure, that Mr Edwards was not just of good character, but of exceptional character.\" Mr Evans said the court was aware of issues with Edwards' health - \"both mental and physical\".\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period. On February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C. Of the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was age between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy. The man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal. Mr Edwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told. No more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nEdwards was one of the BBC 's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors before he left the corporation in April on medical grounds. During his career, he fronted BBC's News At Ten for 20 years and anchored coverage of major national events including announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe was previously the BBC's highest-paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 to \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election {"uri": "8252230134", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:21:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:21:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:20:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7254902124404907, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/3am/celebrity-news/what-huw-edwards-been-convicted-33364825", "title": "Disgraced BBC star Huw Edwards' convictions in full as he 'faces years in jail'", "body": "Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nThe former BBC News anchor, who led the nation through some of the most historical news periods, now faces a maximum of ten years in prison. But what has he been charged with? Edwards, 62, appeared at Westminster Magistrates Court on Wednesday, July 31 where he faced charges of seven Category A, the worst category, 12 Category B, and 22 Category C indecent images of children.\n\nEdwards was previously named by his now ex-wife Vicky Flint as the BBC News reporter at the centre of a scandal involving indecent images of a person under the age of 18. Edwards had been accused of exchanging sexually explicit images with a younger person.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2, 2021, the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard. The indecent images that were sent included seven Category A, the worst, 12 Category B, and 22 Category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told. The final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy. The man told Edwards that the boy was quite young-looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nMr Edwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told. Wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, Edwards spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday. After entering his pleas, Edwards sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards and adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022. In a statement, released on Monday the Metropolitan Police said Edwards was arrested in November last year and charged on June 26. According to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six Category A images, 12 Category B pictures and 19 Category C photographs on WhatsApp - offences contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978.\n\nMr Edwards was one of the BBC's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors before he left the corporation in April on medical grounds. During his career, he fronted BBC's News At Ten for 20 years and anchored coverage of major national events including announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral, as well as the Coronation of King Charles.\n\nHe was previously the BBC's highest-paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 to \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election specials and other television programming, according to the corporation's latest annual report.\n\nFollow Mirror Celebs "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.telegraph.co.uk/news/2024/07/31/huw-edwards-guilty-latest/", "title": "Huw Edwards had indecent images of children 'as young as seven' - follow latest", "body": "Huw Edwards, the former leading BBC presenter, has pleaded guilty to possessing child pornography, including one image of a child believed to be as young as seven years old.\n\nEdwards, 62, who left the corporation last year, admitted at Westminster magistrates court on Wednesday morning to possessing 41 indecent images, seven of which are Category A, the most serious.\n\nEdwards wearing a dark blue suit, light blue tie and white shirt, pleaded guilty to having seven Category A images, 12 category B images and 22 Category C images.\n\nStanding in the centre of glass-panelled dock, Edwards, in a loud clear voice, confirmed his name, address and date of birth during the 26-minute long hearing.\n\nFollow below for latest updates.\n\n11:22AM 'There can be no excuse'\n\nInternet Watch Foundation deputy CEO Heidi Kempster said: \"There can be no excuse.\n\n\"This is criminal material, including images depicting the most extreme category of sexual abuse, which have real and lasting effects on victims.\n\n\"A child's journey to recovery can be dealt a devastating blow when they know images of their abuse continue to be circulated online for others to view.\n\n\"We urge any children or young people worried imagery of themselves may get out of control to use the confidential Report Remove tool run by the IWF and Childline so we can help take down and block this material from being shared on the wider internet.\"\n\n11:14AM 'Prosecution sends a clear message'\n\nClaire Brinton from the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) said: \"Accessing indecent images of underage people perpetuates the sexual exploitation of children, which has deep, long-lasting trauma on these victims.\n\n\"The CPS and the Metropolitan Police were able to prove that Edwards was receiving illegal material involving children via WhatsApp.\n\n\"This prosecution sends a clear message that the CPS, working alongside with the police, will work to bring to justice those who seek to exploit children, wherever that abuse takes place.\"\n\n11:10AM Edwards 'could get suspended sentence'\n\nProsecutor Ian Hope told the court that a suspended sentence might be considered for Edwards.\n\nSetting out the potential penalties under the law, he said that where there is the prospect of rehabilitation a community order and sexual offender treatment programme could be considered as alternatives to a custodial sentence.\n\nSentencing guidelines set the starting point for any jail term for possession of a Category A image at 12 months, with a range of 26 weeks to three years.\n\nThe starting point is 26 weeks for a category B image, and a community order for category C, he said.\n\nAggravating features to be taken into account for Edwards include that the images included moving images, and the young age of the child thought to be seven to nine years old in two of the category A images.\n\nMitigating factors are Edwards' early guilty plea, his previous good character, his mental health issues and what Mr Hope said is \"genuine remorse\".\n\n11:01AM Pictured: Edwards leaves court\n\nHuw Edwards faced a barrage of cameras and photographers as he left court.\n\nHe departed in a black Mercedes with tinted windows.\n\n10:53AM NSPCC: 'No doubt about seriousness of Edwards' crimes'\n\nAn NSPCC spokesperson said: \"Online child sexual abuse offences can have a devastating impact on victims and we should be in no doubt about the seriousness of Edwards' crimes.\n\n\"It can be extremely traumatic for young people to know sexual images of themselves have been shared online. Childline and the IWF's Report Remove tool can help young people who have suffered in this way to get the images removed.\n\n\"We also need to see online platforms do much more to identify and disrupt child abuse in private messaging services in order to safeguard young people.\"\n\nYoung people can contact Childline at www.childline.org.uk or on 0800 11 11.\n\n10:50AM Edwards' defence: 'He did not keep any images'\n\nSpeaking in Edwards' defence, his barrister Philip Evans KC said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\n10:42AM Edwards 'told boy was quite young looking'\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\n10:39AM Watch: Huw Edwards arrives at court 10:36AM One image was of a child between age seven and nine\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between Dec 2020 and Aug 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn Feb 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was age between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\n10:34AM Pictured: Former BBC presenter at court\n\nThe presenter wore a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses to court on Wednesday.\n\nThe former BBC presenter was flanked by eight police officers as he arrived with a blank expression on his face.\n\nA photographer's camera was smashed to pieces in the melee.\n\n10:32AM Huw Edwards pleads guilty\n\nFormer BBC presenter Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to making indecent images of children.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster admitted having 41 images on WhatsApp.\n\nSeven images were Category A, the most serious type.\n\nCategory A images involve penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism.\n\nThe offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\n10:29AM Hello and welcome to our live coverage\n\nWe're bringing you the latest updates on the Huw Edwards case.\n\nThe former BBC presenter Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to making indecent They are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022,\n\nPolice added in their statement that Edwards \"has been bailed\" and will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, July 31.\n\n\"Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case,\" police concluded, warning, \"Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nPer the BBC, Edwards has been accused of having six category A images on a phone, as well as 12 category B photos and 19 category C pictures.\n\nThe Crown Prosecution Service declined to comment on the image categories when contacted by PEOPLE, stating that \"any details on alleged offending will be discussed in court.\"\n\nEdwards, who is the father of five children, was born in Bridgend, Wales, and spent almost all his professional life at the BBC. He was at the helm as the BBC announced the death of Queen Elizabeth on Sept. 8, 2022, would regularly host U.K. general election coverage and was also called upon to anchor the organization's coverage of the late monarch's funeral and King Charles' coronation in May 2023.\n\nHe left the broadcaster in April on medical grounds.\n\n\"Huw Edwards has today resigned and left the BBC,\" the BBC said in a statement on April 22. \"After 40 years of service, Huw has explained that his decision was made on the basis of medical advice from his doctors. The BBC has accepted his resignation which it believes will allow all parties to move forward. We don't believe it appropriate to comment further.\"\n\nWant to keep up with the latest crime coverage? Sign up for PEOPLE's free True Crime newsletter for breaking crime news, ongoing trial coverage and details of intriguing unsolved cases.\n\nIn July 2023, Edwards was named as the man at the center of a sexting scandal after his wife, Vicky Flind, made a statement on behalf of their family.\n\nFlind said at the time that Edwards had been \"suffering from serious mental health issues\" and was \"receiving in-patient hospital care where he'll stay for the foreseeable future\" after suffering \"another serious episode\" amid the scandal.\n\nAllegations had previously been made in The Sun that a \"well-known presenter\" had paid around $45,000 to a young person for sexual pictures over several years. The story was based on an interview with the person's mother and stepfather, who said the contact began when the young person was 17.\n\nHowever, a lawyer for the young person told the BBC that \"nothing inappropriate\" had happened after The Sun's report and allegations came out. A huge media throng had gathered in the hour prior to his arrival in preparation for what could prove to be one of the highest profile media trials of the year.\n\nEdwards was charged with three counts of \"making indecent images of children\" in late June following a months-long Metropolitan Police investigation. The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\nHe is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B images and 19 category C images on his WhatsApp. Category A is defined as \"images involving penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism.\"\n\nEdwards' appearance today is a first hearing. He is in court having not been seen in public for a year. He stopped appearing on the BBC when allegations surfaced in The Sun last summer and exited the corporation in April 2024 on \"medical advice\" after \"40 years of service,\" the corporation said, coming just prior to him taking home his biggest pay packet in five years.\n\nHe was arrested five months before he left the BBC and charged just two months later. While the legal proceedings are active, the BBC is declining comment on Edwards' case and is not saying whether it had continued paying him or whether it had knowledge of his arrest.", "source": The former BBC News presenter appeared at Westminster Magistrates' Court today.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster admitted having 41 on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type. The court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021. Wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, the 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday.\n\nAfter admitting the charges at Westminster Magistrates' Court, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards. He adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nThe 62-year-old journalist was swarmed by photographers as he arrived at court on Wednesday morning, and refused to answer any questions.\n\nMetropolitan Police issued a statement on Monday to confirm the 62-year-old had been charged with making indecent images of children. A police spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation.\n\n\"The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat. Edwards was arrested on 8 November 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. {"uri": "8252349023", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:29:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:29:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:27:46Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7215686440467834, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/huw-edwards-life-now-marriage-33364248", "title": "Huw Edwards' reduced life now - wife 'split', forced move and jail warning", "body": "Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children\n\nHuw Edwards was once the BBC's highest-paid news anchor - but now faces a possible jail sentence.\n\nThe Welsh journalist, 62, has entered guilty pleas to all charges against him at Westminster Magistrates' Court. The court heard he was sent 41 indecent images of children by an adult male on WhatsApp between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nSix were Category A, the most serious classification, of which the estimated age of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine. Edwards told the man not to send any illegal images, the court heard.\n\nToday marked the first time the former BBC presenter was seen publicly since July 2023. He was arrested in November 2023 and officially resigned from the BBC in April 2024.\n\nEdwards is best known for presenting the Six O'Clock News and was a key reporter at Prince William and Kate Middleton's wedding. He also announced Queen Elizabeth's death in 2022 and led the BBC's coverage of her funeral.\n\nEdwards is said to have moved out of his family home in Dulwich, south London, after splitting from his wife Vicky Flind, 62. It is believed he has had to move to another property in the capital and has been splitting his time between there and his native Wales. The former couple have reportedly not yet divorced. They share five grown-up children - three sons and two daughters.\n\nA source told The Sun: \"They separated quite a long time ago but have not announced it publicly. Huw has been living elsewhere for a while.\" Vicky also works in television and was previously the editor of the BBC's This Week before she moved to ITV's rival politics show Peston, while she also worked on Britain's Next Prime Minister.\n\nEdwards has not appeared on any TV shows since his last BBC News appearance on July 5, 2023. He was suspended by the broadcaster following separate allegations made against him. In January of this year, it was reported that Edwards was 'too unwell' to discuss his future at the BBC and was still recovering from a 'serious episode'. He has a history of mental health and depression.\n\nHe is a religious man and has always gone to church weekly to practise his Christian faith. He was previously the Vice President of the National Churches Trust and told Sorted Magazine last year that churches \"have a vital role to play in moments of national importance; bringing people together, providing quiet spaces for reflection and prayer, and places for communities to gather and share\".\n\nBut on Tuesday, Edwards was stripped of his role at the trust. The charity, which supports the UK's churches to maintain their historic sites and buildings, said in a statement: \"In light of the news yesterday, the National Churches Trust has confirmed that Huw Edwards is no longer a Vice President for the charity. We are shocked and saddened by the recent developments.\"\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six Category A images, 12 Category B pictures and 19 Category C photographs on WhatsApp - offences contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period. The final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a Category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court was told Edwards' offending had a starting point of 12 months in prison. However his barrister, Philip Evans KC, said there were mitigating factors and the sentence should be suspended.\n\nHe said: \"There are serious issues in relation to Mr Edwards health, both physical and mental, at the time of the offending and now.\" Edwards has now been bailed for pre-sentence reports.\n\nProsecutor Ian Hope told the court that a suspended sentence might be considered for the newsreader. Setting out the potential penalties under the law, he said that where there is the prospect of rehabilitation, a community order and sexual offender treatment programme could be considered as alternatives to a custodial sentence.\n\nSentencing guidelines set the starting point for any jail term for possession of a Category A image at 12 months, with a range of 26 weeks to three years. The starting point is 26 weeks for a category B image, and a community order for category C, he said.\n\nAggravating features to be taken into account for Edwards include that the images included moving images, and the young age of the child thought to be seven to nine years old in two of the category A images.\n\nMitigating factors are Edwards' early guilty plea, his previous good character, his mental health issues and what Mr Hope said is \"genuine remorse\".\n\nThe Metropolitan Police has today said the allegations are separate from other claims that were widely reported and investigated last year. {"uri": "8252327373", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:16:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:16:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:14:29Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7176470756530762, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/law-order/3036851-fall-from-grace-former-bbc-anchor-huw-edwards-pleads-guilty-to-child-indecency-charges", "title": "Fall from Grace: Former BBC Anchor Huw Edwards Pleads Guilty to Child Indecency Charges | Law-Order", "body": "Former British TV presenter Huw Edwards, the long-time face of the BBC's flagship news programme, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to three counts of making indecent pictures of children. Edwards was the BBC's highest paid journalist and top news anchor until he quit in April, following allegations he had paid a young person thousands of pounds for sexually explicit photos, something which is unconnected to the criminal charges.\n\nThe 62-year-old was a household name in Britain for more than two decades, announcing the death of Queen Elizabeth to the nation in 2022 and leading coverage of elections, royal weddings and the 2012 Olympics. But he has not been on TV screens for a year and Wednesday's court appearance, which caps a dramatic fall from grace, was his first in public since then.\n\nEdwards made his way through a throng of photographers and camera crews into London's Westminster Magistrates' Court, where he admitted having been sent several indecent images of children between December 2020 and August 2021. Asked if he wished to indicate a plea to the three charges, which related to three different categories of indecent images, Edwards said: \"Guilty\".\n\nJudge Paul Goldspring said Edwards would be sentenced on Sept. 16 and that \"all options\", including an immediate prison sentence, would be considered. During the 25-minute hearing, prosecutor Ian Hope said Edwards had been sent a total of 377 sexually explicit images by an adult male on WhatsApp, 41 of which were indecent, illegal images of children.\n\nPORNOGRAPHIC VIDEOS Hope said seven of the 41 images were of the most serious kind and that two of those seven were pornographic videos of a child possibly aged between seven and nine years old.\n\nThe last indecent image was sent to Edwards in August 2021, when the man who sent it said \"the male in the film was quite young-looking and that he has more images which are illegal\", Hope said. He added that Edwards told the male \"not to send him illegal images and no more are sent from this point\", though the chat continues and further legal pornographic images were sent.\n\nEdwards' lawyer Philip Evans emphasised that the charges to which his client had indicated guilty pleas related only to images that were sent to him via WhatsApp. \"There is no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has in any way made, in the traditional sense of the word, any images in any physical way or created any images of any sort,\" Evans said.\n\nEdwards made no comment as he left the court building. Claire Brinton of Britain's Crown Prosecution Service said in a statement: \"Accessing indecent images of underage people perpetuates the sexual exploitation of children, which has deep, long-lasting "sim": 0.7137255072593689, "url": "https://www.shropshirestar.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/31/ex-bbc-presenter-huw-edwards-admits-having-images-of-children-as-young-as-seven/", "title": "Ex-BBC presenter Huw Edwards admits having images of children as young as seven", "body": "Westminster Magistrates' Court heard Edwards was sent hundreds of sexual images on WhatsApp.\n\nFormer BBC presenter Huw Edwards has admitted accessing indecent photographs of children as young as seven after a man he met online sent him hundreds of sexual images on WhatsApp.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court was told seven of the 41 indecent images sent to the veteran broadcaster by the unnamed male were of the most serious type.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy, with the man telling the newsreader the child was \"quite young looking\" and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told in a 26-minute hearing.\n\nHe appeared nervous, fidgeting with his hands as Chief Magistrate Paul Goldspring told him he would not be sentencing him on Wednesday.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021, the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, to which Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nNo more indecent images more were sent after August 2021, but the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nSpeaking in Edwards' defence, his barrister Philip Evans KC said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nMr Evans said the defendant had \"both mental and physical\" health issues.\n\nHe told the court: \"It is obvious to the court, I'm sure, that Mr Edwards was not just of good character, but of exceptional character.\"\n\nThe broadcaster was emotionless as he pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nAfter admitting the charges, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards.\n\nHe adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nMr Hope told the court that a suspended sentence might be considered for Edwards.\n\nSetting out the potential penalties under the law, he said that where there is the prospect of rehabilitation a community order and sexual offender treatment programme could be considered as alternatives to a custodial sentence.\n\nSentencing guidelines set the starting point for any jail term for possession of a Category A image at 12 months, with a range of 26 weeks to three years.\n\nThe starting point is 26 weeks for a category B image, and a community order for category C, he said.\n\nAggravating features to be taken into account for Edwards include that the images included moving images, and the young age of the child thought to be seven to nine years old in two of the category A images.\n\nMitigating factors are Edwards' early guilty plea, his previous good character, his mental health issues and what Mr Hope said is \"genuine remorse\".\n\nHe faced a barrage of cameras and photographers as he left court, but made no comment as he departed in a black Mercedes with tinted windows.\n\nClaire Brinton, from the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS), said: \"Accessing indecent images of underage people perpetuates the sexual exploitation of children, which has deep, long-lasting trauma on these victims.\n\n\"The CPS and the Metropolitan Police were able to prove that Edwards was receiving illegal material involving children via WhatsApp.\n\n\"This prosecution sends a clear message that the CPS, working alongside with the police, will work to bring to justice those who seek to exploit children, wherever that abuse takes place.\"\n\nEdwards will Edwards arrives at court to face indecent...", "body": "Former BBC presenter Huw Edwards has arrived at court to face charges of making indecent images of children.\n\nThe 62-year-old is alleged to have committed three offences between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster is accused of having had 37 photographs on WhatsApp, including six of the most serious type.\n\nEdwards arrived at Westminster Magistrates' Court shortly before 9.15am on Wednesday wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses.\n\nHe refused to answer any questions from the journalists present.\n\nPhotographers were knocked to the ground as they scrambled to get to the broadcaster as he entered the court building flanked by police officers.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police said he was arrested in November last year and charged on June 26.\n\nHuw Edwards was surrounded by police as he arrived at Westminster Magistrates\u00b4 Court on Wednesday morning (Jonathan Brady/PA)\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp - offences contrary to sections 1(1)(a) He pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nEdwards, 62, had been involved in an online chat with another adult male on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, with the man sending him 377 sexual images - 41 of which, were images of children. The court heard how the children in the Category A images were estimated to be between the ages of 13 and 15, but one was of age between seven and nine.\n\nThe bulk of the images sent via WhatsApp were sent during a two-month period. On February 2, 2021, the male who was engaging in conversation with Edwards asked whether what he was sending was too young. The court heard how Edwards informed him not to send underage images.\n\nHowever, they went on to continue to send legal pornographic images to one another until April 2022. The final indecent image which was sent in August 2021 was a Category A film, featuring a young male. Edwards appeared emotionless as he pleaded guilty in court. After admitting the charges, the anchor who became famous for covering historic events sat gazing into the distance as he tilted his head slightly upwards.\n\nIn a statement, released on Monday the Metropolitan Police said Edwards was arrested in November last year and charged on June 26. According to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six Category A images, 12 Category B pictures and 19 Category C photographs on WhatsApp - offences contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978.\n\nThe offences with which Mr Edwards was charged with carry a maximum sentence of ten years. I am doing this primarily out of concern for his mental well-being and to protect our children.\n\n\"Huw is suffering from serious mental health issues. As is well documented, he has been treated for severe depression in recent years. The events of the last few days have greatly worsened matters, he has suffered another serious episode and is now receiving in-patient hospital care where he'll stay for the foreseeable future.\n\n\"Once well enough to do so, he intends to respond to the stories that have been published. To be clear Huw was first told that there were allegations being made against him last Thursday. In the circumstances and given Huw's condition I would like to ask that the privacy of my family and everyone else caught up in these upsetting events is respected. I know that Huw is deeply sorry that so many colleagues have been impacted by the recent media speculation. He resigned in April.\n\nHuw Edwards was one of the main faces at the BBC until his departure. (File)\n\nLondon:\n\nFormer British TV news presenter Huw Edwards, a household name in Britain, has been charged with three counts of making indecent pictures of children, police said on Monday.\n\nEdwards, 62, was the BBC's highest paid news presenter and anchored the broadcaster's \"BBC News at Ten\" bulletin for more than two decades. He resigned in April.\n\nHe has been charged with three counts of making an indecent photograph or pseudo-photograph of a child relating to images found on a child's phone, according to court documents.\n\n\"The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat,\" a London police spokesperson said.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on 8 November, 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\"\n\nHe was bailed to appear at London's Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.\n\nEdwards was one of the main faces at the BBC until his departure, announcing the death of Queen Elizabeth to the nation, and leading coverage of the biggest events in Britain since the turn of the century, including elections, royal weddings and the 2012 Olympics.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nHe quit on medical advice after allegations emerged that he had paid a young He engaged in an online conversation with an adult man between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nThe man sent Huw 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children. The indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C, the court heard during his first public appearance in over a year.\n\nA category A film featuring a young boy was amongst content sent to Huw. The man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal. Edwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022. But before that, 41 indecent images of children were sent. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nOn February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard. Of the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was age between seven and nine, the magistrates' court was told.\n\nToday, Edwards was emotionless as he pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children. After admitting charges, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards. He adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' was told Edwards' offending had a starting point of 12 months in prison. However his barrister, Philip Evans KC, told the court that there were mitigating factors and the sentence should be suspended. He said: \"There are serious issues in relation to Mr Edwards health, both physical and mental, at the time of the offending and now.\"\n\nSpeaking after the hearing, Claire Brinton, of the Crown Prosecution Service, said: \"Accessing indecent images of underage people perpetuates the sexual exploitation of children, which has deep, long-lasting trauma on these victims.\n\n\"The CPS and the Metropolitan Police were able to prove that Edwards was receiving illegal material involving children via WhatsApp. This prosecution sends a clear message that the CPS, working alongside with the police, will work to bring to justice those who seek to exploit children, wherever that abuse takes place.\"\n\nFollow Mirror Celebs on TikTok, Snapchat, Instagram, Twitter, Facebook, YouTube and He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service,\" the Met Police said. \"He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, 31 July. Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nBritish tabloid The Sun first published news of the charges against Edward.\n\nEdwards is accused of having illegal images of children on his WhatsApp, including six so-called category A images, deemed the most severe under U.K. law.\n\nThe BBC suspended Edwards, the network's best-paid and most high-profile news presenter, in July last year, over allegations, also made by The Sun, that he paid a teenager for sexually-explicit photos. Police did not take any action against Edwards, saying there was no evidence that a criminal offence had been committed. The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\nHe is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B images and 19 category C images on his WhatsApp. Category A is defined as \"images involving penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism.\"\n\nEdwards was appearing in court having not been seen in public for a year. He stopped appearing on the BBC when allegations surfaced in The Sun last summer and exited the corporation in April 2024 on \"medical advice\" after \"40 years of service,\" the corporation said, coming just prior to him taking home his biggest pay packet in five years.\n\nHe was arrested five months before he left the BBC and charged just two months later. making indecent images of children", "body": "Former BBC news anchor Huw Edwards, one of the most recognisable faces on UK television, on Wednesday, pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nThe 62-year-old, who resigned from the BBC in April on \"medical advice\", six months after he was initially arrested, faces a maximum prison sentence of 10 years and a minimum of 12 months.\n\nWearing a dark suit and blue tie, Edwards was emotionless as he admitted having 41 indecent images of children on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nThe offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021, amended from the initial chargesheet which ran to April 2022.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court in London heard that Edwards had received 377 sexual images from a man on WhatsApp, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nOf the most serious images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nEdwards had told the man not to send any illegal images, the court heard.\n\nHe was released on conditional bail until his next hearing on September 16, when he could be sentenced.\n\nEdwards was the BBC's lead presenter on key events, such as the death and funeral of Queen Elizabeth II, but was suspended in July 2023 when allegations first emerged.\n\nHe had also been the anchor of the BBC's flagship 10pm news programme since 2003.\n\nHe quit on April 22 after 40 years with the broadcaster.\n\nAs the accusations became front-page news last July, Edwards's wife Vicky Flind said the father-of-five was \"suffering from serious mental health issues\" and had been admitted to hospital.\n\nEdwards himself has not publicly commented on the allegations.\n\nThe BBC's brand has been built on public trust but the broadcaster has been rocked in recent years by scandals which saw some big names revealed as serial sex offenders.", He resigned in April.\n\nFormer British TV news presenter Huw Edwards, a household name in Britain, has been charged with three counts of making indecent pictures of children, police said on Monday.\n\nEdwards, 62, was the BBC's highest paid news presenter and anchored the broadcaster's \"BBC News at Ten\" bulletin for more than two decades. He resigned in April.\n\nHe has been charged with three counts of making an indecent photograph or pseudo-photograph of a child relating to images found on a child's phone, according to court documents.\n\n\"The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat,\" a London police spokesperson said.\n\nAlso Read | Unnamed BBC anchor who allegedly paid teen for sexual photos identified by wife\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on 8 November, 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, 26 June following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\"\n\nHe was bailed to appear at London's Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.\n\nEdwards was one of the main faces at the BBC until his departure, announcing the death of Queen Elizabeth to the nation, and leading coverage of the biggest events in Britain since the turn of the century, "sim": 0.7019608020782471, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/31/ex-bbc-presenter-huw-edwards-admits-having-images-of-children-as-young-as-seven/", "title": "Ex-BBC presenter Huw Edwards admits having images of children as young as seven", "body": "Westminster Magistrates' Court heard Edwards was sent hundreds of sexual images on WhatsApp.\n\nFormer BBC presenter Huw Edwards has admitted accessing indecent photographs of children as young as seven after a man he met online sent him hundreds of sexual images on WhatsApp.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court was told seven of the 41 indecent images sent to the veteran broadcaster by the unnamed male were of the most serious type.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy, with the man telling the newsreader the child was \"quite young looking\" and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nHe appeared nervous, fidgeting with his hands as Chief Magistrate Paul Goldspring told him he would not be sentencing him on Wednesday.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021, the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, to which Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nNo more indecent images more were sent after August 2021, but the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nMr Evans said the defendant had \"both mental and physical\" health issues.\n\nHe told the court: \"It is obvious to the court, I'm sure, that Mr Edwards was not just of good character, but of exceptional character.\"\n\nThe broadcaster was emotionless as he pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nAfter admitting the charges, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards.\n\nHe adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nSetting out the potential penalties under the law, he said that where there is the prospect of rehabilitation a community order and sexual offender treatment programme could be considered as alternatives to a custodial sentence.\n\nSentencing guidelines set the starting point for any jail term for possession of a Category A image at 12 months, with a range of 26 weeks to three years.\n\nThe starting point is 26 weeks for a category B image, and a community order for category C, he said.\n\nAggravating features to be taken into account for Edwards include that the images included moving images, and the young age of the child thought to be seven to nine years old in two of the category A images.\n\nMitigating factors are Edwards' early guilty plea, his previous good character, his mental health issues and what Mr Hope said is \"genuine remorse\".\n\nHe faced a barrage of cameras and photographers as he left court, but made no comment as he departed in a black Mercedes with tinted windows.\n\nClaire Brinton, from the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS), said: \"Accessing indecent images of underage people perpetuates the sexual exploitation of children, which has deep, long-lasting trauma on these victims.\n\n\"The CPS and the Metropolitan Police were able to prove that Edwards was receiving illegal material involving children via WhatsApp.\n\n\"This prosecution sends a clear message that the CPS, working alongside with the police, will work to bring to justice those who seek to exploit children, wherever that abuse takes place.\"\n\nEdwards will be appear at the same court again on September 16.", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Guernsey Press"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": On Monday the police issued a warning about those curbs.\n\n\"Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nMr. Edwards was born in Bridgend in Wales in 1961 and worked for the BBC for four decades, Edwards appeared in a London court on Wednesday and indicated guilty pleas to three counts of making indecent pictures of children.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster admitted having 41 images on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nWearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, the 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday.\n\nAfter he entered his pleas, Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2njd, 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nIf found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison.\n\nEdwards was one of the BBC's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors before he left the corporation in April on medical grounds.\n\nDuring his career, he fronted BBC's News At Ten for 20 years and anchored coverage of major national events including announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe was previously the BBC's highest-paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 to \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election specials and other television programming, according to the
