"news", "sim": 0.6980392336845398, "url": "https://internewscast.com/news/former-bbc-star-huw-edwards-confesses-to-possessing-inappropriate-images-of-children-he-explains-that-the-photos-which-include-one-of-a-child-under-nine-years-old-were-shared-with-him-by-another/", "title": "Former BBC Star, Huw Edwards, confesses to possessing inappropriate images of children: He explains that the photos, which include one of a child under nine years old, were shared with him by another predator on WhatsApp. - Internewscast Journal", "body": "Former BBC news star Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to making indecent images of children - and claimed the images 'were sent to him by another paedophile'.\n\nEdwards, 62, kept seven category 'A' images of the very worse kind on his phone and shared them on WhatsApp with other child sex offenders.\n\nThe images showed children aged between seven and 14, Westminster Magistrates' Court heard this morning.\n\nThe veteran news broadcaster, who announced the death of Queen Elizabeth II and presented coverage of her funeral had a total of 41 foul pictures.\n\nHis career is over - and he faces up to 10 years in jail, although he likely to escape custody because of prison overcrowding.\n\nEdwards today admitted three charges of making indecent photographs date between December 2020 and August 2022.\n\nEdwards was arrested on November 8 last year and charged on June 26.\n\nThe father-of-five moved out of the family home in Dulwich after separating from his wife.\n\nHe has been living in a flat in Earlsfield, south west London.\n\nThe Welshman resigned from the BBC three months ago after a glittering career spanning almost 40 years.\n\nSurrounded by police officers, Edwards arrived at Westminster Magistrates' Court wearing black sunglasses, a blue tie, white shirt and black suit.\n\nEdwards, of Wandsworth, southwest London, spoke to confirm his date of birth, address and admit the three charges.\n\nHe kept seven category A images, the most serious classification of indecent images, on a phone.\n\nEdwards also made 12 category B pictures and 22 category C photographs.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978.\n\nCategory A involves images involving penetrative sexual activity, sexual activity with an animal or sadism; Category B covers images which show non-penetrative sexual activity; while Category C is for indecent images not within categories B or C.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was age between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nMr Edwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nEdwards presented the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (now the Prince and Princess of Wales) in 2011 and also the funeral of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, in 2021.\n\nThe reputation of the BBC has been destroyed by one paedophile scandal after another dating back over half a century.\n\nIn 2001 BBC presenter and music impresario Jonathan King was convicted of sexual offences committed between 1983 and 1987 against five boys aged 14 and 15 and was jailed for seven years.\n\nChris Denning, one of the original Radio 1 presenters, who was a regular at 'The Walton Hop' with King, was jailed for 18 months for gross indecency with a child and in 1988 for three years for indecent assault on a 13-year-old boy and possession of indecent photographs.\n\nIn 2008, he was extradited from Britain to Slovakia, where he was jailed in October for five years for producing child pornography.\n\nIn 2014 Denning was jailed for 13 years after he admitted to a total to 40 sexual offences committed from 1967 to 1987 relating to 26 male victims, the youngest of whom was nine years old.\n\nIn 2016, Denning was given another 13 years after pleaded guilty to 21 sex offences against 11 boys between 1969 and 1986, the youngest of whom was aged eight.\n\nIn 2007 Actor Chris Langham, star of the BBC's 'In The Thick of It' was found guilty of downloading 15 child sexual abuse images and videos.\n\nOne of the videos showed the 'sadistic brutalisation of an eight-year-old girl.'\n\nHe was sentenced to ten months in prison and was placed on the sexual offenders register for ten years\n\nLast year the BBC was criticised for putting all the shows of 'In The Thick of It' back in on the BBC iPlayer.\n\nIn 2013 Stuart Hall,the commentator and presenter of 'It's A Knockout' was jailed for 30 months for two offences of indecent assault against a girl of 13 and another against a girl under 16.\n\nThe following year legendary children's presenter and entertainer Rolf Harris was jailed five years and nine months after he was convicted of 12 charges of indecent assault against four girls - including one aged seven.\n\nVeteran Radio I presenter Dave Lee Travis was convicted of assaulting an adult researcher on the Mrs Merton show in 2014 and was sentenced to three months in prison, suspended for two years.\n\nUp to 450 young people were assaulted by another 'face of the BBC' Jimmy Savile.\n\nPolice recorded 199 crimes in 17 police force areas in which Savile was a suspect, among them 31 allegations of rape.\n\nThe crimes stretched 1955 to 2009 and allegations included the abuse of desperately ill children and necrophilia with corpses at included Leeds General Infirmary mortuary.\n\nBBC bosses were accused of staging various cover-ups to protect Savile. who committed the offences at hospitals and locations across the country including BBC Television Centre.\n\nEdwards had long been a fixture in the coverage of major political and royal events, announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe also anchored the BBC's broadcast of the King's coronation last year.\n\nLast week the BBC confirmed Edwards was paid more than \u00a3475,000 in 2023/24 before he resigned and left.\n\nThe veteran newsreader was paid between \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election specials and other television programming, according to the BBC's annual report.\n\nThis marked an increase from 2022/23, when he was paid between \u00a3435,000 and 439,999 for 180 days presenting on BBC One, as well as news specials.\n\nThroughout the years, Edwards presented the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (now the Prince and Princess of Wales) in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, in 2021.\n\nThe BBC News At Ten presenter was also the broadcaster's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance, and took over election coverage from the long-serving David Dimbleby in 2019.", "source": {"uri": He had also been the anchor of the BBC's flagship 10pm news programme since 2003. {"uri": "8252170560", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:45:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:45:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:45:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6941176652908325, "url": "https://www.gloucestershirelive.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/huw-edwards-pleads-guilty-making-9448974", "title": "Huw Edwards pleads guilty to making indecent images of children", "body": "Former BBC presenter Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to making indecent images of children. The veteran broadcaster admitted having 41 on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021. Wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, the 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday.\n\nHe was emotionless as he pleaded guilty. After admitting the charges, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards. He adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2, 2021, the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard. The indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was age between seven and nine, the court was told. The final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young-looking and that he had more images which were illegal. Mr Edwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told. No more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nSpeaking in Edwards' defence, his barrister Philip Evans KC said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort. It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat. Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nEdwards will be sentenced at Westminster Magistrates' Court on September 16. Edwards stood in the dock as Chief Magistrate Paul Goldspring addressed him on his bail conditions.\n\nEdwards appeared nervous, fidgeting with his hands, before confirming that he understood the conditions. He then left the courtroom. Ian Hope, prosecuting, has asked for Edwards' address to be \"restricted\" because of the \"protests\" outside court. He said it was a \"very volatile situation\".\n\nEdwards first spoke to confirm his name, date of birth and address before the charges were read out during the hearing at Westminster Magistrates' Court.\n\nThe 62-year-old looked calm and collected as he sat in the dock. He glanced at members of the press sitting in the public gallery, before staring straight ahead as proceedings began.\n\nHe appeared emotionless as he pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children. After admitting the charges at Westminster Magistrates' Court, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards.\n\nIn a statement, released on Monday the Metropolitan Police said he was arrested in November last year and charged on June 26.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp - offences contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978.\n\nEdwards was one of the BBC's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors before he left the corporation in April on medical grounds.\n\nDuring his career, he fronted BBC's News At Ten for 20 years and anchored coverage of major national events including announcing Queen Elizabeth {"uri": "8252226247", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:19:37", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:19:37Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:18:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://timesofindia.indiatimes.com/world/uk/ex-bbc-news-presenter-huw-edwards-pleads-guilty-to-indecent-child-pictures-charges/articleshow/112165492.cms", "title": "Ex-BBC news presenter Huw Edwards pleads guilty to indecent child pictures charges - Times of India", "body": "LONDON: Former BBC TV news presenter Huw Edwards, a household name in Britain, pleaded guilty on Wednesday to three counts of making indecent pictures of children.\n\nEdwards, 62, who was the BBC's highest paid journalist and top news anchor until he quit in April, had arrived at London's Westminster Magistrates' Court wearing sunglasses through a throng of photographers and camera crews.\n\nAfter confirming his identity, he was asked if he wished to indicate a plea to the three charges, which relate to three different categories of indecent images. Edwards said: \"Guilty\".\n\nJudge Paul Goldspring said Edwards would be sentenced on Sept. 16.\n\nDuring the 25-minute hearing, prosecutor Ian Hope said the 41 still or moving images had been sent to Edwards by an adult male on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nHope added that seven of the 41 images were of the most serious kind and that two of that seven were pornographic videos of a child possibly aged seven and nine years old.\n\nEdwards' lawyer Philip Evans emphasised that the charges to which his client had indicated guilty pleas related only to images that were sent to him via WhatsApp.\n\n\"There is no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has in any way made, in the traditional sense of the word, any images in any physical way or created any images of any sort,\" Evans said.\n\nEdwards, who announced the death of Queen Elizabeth to the nation in 2022 and led coverage of elections, royal weddings and the 2012 Olympics, has not been on TV screens for a year and the court appearance was his first in public since then.\n\nHe quit in April on medical advice after newspaper allegations last year that he had paid a young person thousands of pounds for {"uri": "8252245328", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:31:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:31:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:30:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.plymouthherald.co.uk/news/uk-world-news/huw-edwards-pleads-guilty-making-9448974", "title": "Huw Edwards pleads guilty to making indecent images of children", "body": "Former BBC presenter Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to making indecent images of children. The veteran broadcaster admitted having 41 on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021. Wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, the 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday.\n\nHe was emotionless as he pleaded guilty. After admitting the charges, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards. He adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2, 2021, the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard. The indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was age between seven and nine, the court was told. The final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young-looking and that he had more images which were illegal. Mr Edwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told. No more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nSpeaking in Edwards' defence, his barrister Philip Evans KC said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort. It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat. Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nMr Evans said the broadcaster had \"both mental and physical\" health issues.\n\nHe told the court: \"It is obvious to the court, I'm sure, that Mr Edwards was not just of good character, but of exceptional character.\"\n\nMr Evans said the court was aware of issues with Edwards' health - \"both mental and physical\".\n\nProsecutor Mr Hope told the court that a suspended sentence might be considered for Edwards. Setting out the potential penalties under the law, he said that where there is the prospect of rehabilitation a community order and sexual offender treatment programme could be considered as alternatives to a custodial sentence.\n\nSentencing guidelines set the starting point for any jail term for possession of a Category A image at 12 months, with a range of 26 weeks to three years. The starting point is 26 weeks for a category B image, and a community order for category C, he said.\n\nAggravating features to be taken into account for Edwards include that the images included moving images and the young age of the child thought to be seven to nine years old in two of the category A images. Mitigating factors are Edwards' early guilty plea, his previous good character, his mental health issues and what Mr Hope said is \"genuine remorse\".\n\nEdwards was bailed and will be sentenced at Westminster Magistrates' Court on September 16. He stood in the dock as Chief Magistrate Paul Goldspring addressed him on his bail conditions.\n\nEdwards appeared nervous, fidgeting with his hands, before confirming that he understood the conditions. He then left the courtroom. The hearing lasted 26 minutes in total.\n\nEdwards faced a barrage of cameras and photographers as he left court. He departed in a black Mercedes with tinted windows without making any comment.", "source": {"uri": "plymouthherald.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Plymouth Herald"}, "authors": [{"uri": The 62-year-old, once regarded as one of the most trusted faces at the Beeb, admitted having 41 on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021. Wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, Edwards spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of today's hearing.\n\nAfter entering his pleas, Edwards sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards, and adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him. The court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nREAD: Forecasters issue verdict on when Stoke-on-Trent's heat blast will end | Temperatures have reached around 27C across North Staffordshire this week\n\nREAD: 'Warped' predator posed as 13-year-old girl to have sex chats with older men | The judge told him that portraying himself as a 12 or 13-year-old girl to another pervert on Kik was 'stoking the flames of his warped cravings and your own'\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period. On February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C. Of the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy. The man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told. No more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nSpeaking in Edwards' defence, his barrister Philip Evans KC said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort. It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat. Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nProsecutor Ian Hope told the court that a suspended sentence might be considered for Edwards. Setting out the potential penalties under the law, he said that where there is the prospect of rehabilitation a community order and sexual offender treatment programme could be considered as alternatives to a custodial sentence.\n\nSentencing guidelines set the starting point for any jail term for possession of a Category A image at 12 months, with a range of 26 weeks to three years.\n\nThe starting point is 26 weeks for a category B image, and a community order for category C, he said. Aggravating features to be taken into account for Edwards include that the images included moving images, and the young age of the child thought to be seven to nine years old in two of the category A images.\n\nMitigating factors are Edwards' early guilty plea, his previous good character, his mental health issues and what Mr Hope said is \"genuine remorse\".\n\nEdwards was bailed and will next appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on September 16. Speaking after this morning's hearing Claire Brinton from the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS) said: \"Accessing indecent images of underage people perpetuates the sexual exploitation of children, which has deep, long-lasting trauma on these victims.\n\n\"The CPS and the Metropolitan Police were able to prove that Edwards was receiving illegal material involving children via WhatsApp. This prosecution sends a clear message that the CPS, working alongside with the police, will work to bring to justice those who seek to exploit children, wherever that abuse takes place.\"\n\nInternet Watch Foundation deputy CEO Heidi Kempster said: \"There can be no excuse. This is criminal material, including images depicting the most extreme category of sexual abuse, which have real and lasting effects on victims.\n\n\"A child's journey to recovery can be dealt a devastating blow when they know images of their abuse continue to be circulated online for others to view. We urge any children or young people worried imagery of themselves may get out of control to use the confidential Report Remove tool run by the IWF and Childline so we can help take down and block this material from being shared on the wider internet.\"\n\nWant more court and crime news? {"uri": "8251568721", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "01:31:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T01:31:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T01:30:14Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.686274528503418, "url": "https://www.perthnow.com.au/entertainment/tv/former-bbc-presenter-huw-edwards-splits-with-wife-as-he-faces-court-for-making-indecent-images-of-children-c-15537635", "title": "TV star 'splits from wife' amid indecent child image case", "body": "Huw Edwards has split from his TV producer wife, it was claimed last night.\n\nEdwards, 62, has allegedly moved out of the family home in Dulwich, south London, which he shared with Vicky Flind.\n\nIt is believed that the former News at Ten presenter has been dividing his time between a home in Wandsworth, south-west London, and his native Wales.\n\nEdwards is due at Westminster Magistrates' Court in central London today, having been accused of child pornography offences after 37 indecent images were allegedly shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\nHe faces three counts relating to offences alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nEdwards is accused of having six category A images, the most serious classification of indecent images, on a phone. He is also accused of having 12 category B and 19 category C photographs.\n\nHe got engaged to Ms Flind in 1993, and the couple have three sons and two daughters.\n\nSpeaking of their split, a source told The Sun: \"They separated quite a long time ago but have not announced it publicly.\"\n\nThey added: \"Huw has been living elsewhere for a while.\"\n\nIn April, Edwards resigned from the BBC on medical grounds and left without a payout despite having two years on his contract which could have meant he was entitled to about \u00a3900,000 ($1,766,520)\n\nHe then moved in with his mother in Wales. But it was revealed earlier this week that Edwards had been arrested on November 8 last year and charged just over a month ago on June 26 following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\nEdwards was the BBC's highest-paid news anchor and its third-highest-paid star last year -- despite being off the air during the nine months before he resigned on medical grounds in April.\n\nHe received a bumper raise of about \u00a340,000 ($78,512) to earn a salary as high as \u00a3479,999 (more than $942,142), and rose one place in the pay rankings behind only Match Of The Day host Gary Lineker and Radio 2 breakfast host Zoe Ball.\n\nIt is understood Edwards received the 9 per cent pay increase for his work covering the Queen's death in September 2022 and the King's Coronation in 2023.\n\nEdwards spent almost four decades at the BBC, originally spending 12 years as a parliamentary correspondent for BBC Wales before he was elevated to the host of the Six O'Clock Of these 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nMost of them -- 36 files -- were sent during a two-month period.\n\nIn February 2021, the man asked Edwards whether the files he was sending contained images of people who were too young, the court heard. The ex-BBC employee asked the man not to send anything illegal.\n\nThe court was told that the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nAccording to the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS), \"making\" indecent and prohibited images of children can include receiving an image via social media, even if unsolicited and even if part of a group.\n\nClaire Brinton of the CPS said in a statement on Wednesday, \"Accessing indecent images of underage people perpetuates the sexual exploitation of children, which has deep, long-lasting trauma on these victims.\"\n\nThe over 'indecent child sex pictures'", "body": "Staff at the Beeb were said to be left stunned by the development\n\nTHE BBC was \"blindsided\" after Huw Edwards was charged with making 37 indecent images of children.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster, 62, faces three charges over alleged activity between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nThe father-of-five, who has been separated from his wife Vicky Flind for months, is due to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court tomorrow.\n\nHe is now accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978.\n\nIf found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years' imprisonment.\n\nHowever, a BBC insider revealed the Beeb only found out about the charges just hours before they were made public, according to The Times.\n\nStaff at the corporation were said to be left stunned by the development and claimed senior management must have been unaware.\n\nA senior source told The Times: \"The BBC was informed by the Met Police when a call came through [on Monday].\n\n\"It will be quite a moment when he appears in Westminster magistrates' court on Wednesday morning.\n\n\"The court artists will be there to capture the moment when the man who announced the death of the Queen to the nation is up before Mr or Mrs magistrate.\"\n\nHe is also kept his arrest \"completely secret\" from his friends for eight months, MailOnline reported.\n\nOne former BBC colleague and friend told the newspaper: \"Huw kept his arrest completely secret.\n\n\"It turns out he was arrested four months later and nobody knew. I had no idea until he was charged.\"\n\nAnother said: \"It's a mess - and tragic for all concerned.\"\n\nEdwards was one of the BBC's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors before he left the corporation earlier this year.\n\nDuring his career, he fronted BBC's News At Ten for 20 years and anchored coverage of major national events.\n\nThese included announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe also helmed the BBC's broadcast of the King's coronation last year.\n\nThroughout the years he presented the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018 and the funeral of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, in 2021.\n\nThe BBC News At Ten presenter was also the broadcaster's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance.\n\nHe took over election coverage from the long-serving David Dimbleby in 2019.\n\nBefore he stepped down, he was the BBC's highest-paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24.\n\nHis duties included 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election specials and other television programming, according to the BBC's latest annual report.\n\nA Met Police spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a police investigation.\n\n\"The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on November 8, 2023. were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court Edwards admits having indecent images of kids...", "body": "Disgraced BBC News anchor Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to possessing child pornography, including one image of a child believed to be as young as 7 years old.\n\nThe former host of the BBC's flagship \"News at Ten\" program -- and one of the most recognizable faces on British TV -- hid his face behind a pair of blacked-out shades as he arrived at Westminster Magistrates Court in London on Wednesday.\n\nThe veteran journalist, 62, who quit the BBC after 40 years in April 2023, admitted to possessing 41 indecent images, seven of which are Category A -- the most serious offense.\n\nThe category A images were mostly of children aged 13 to 15, the court heard.\n\nThe married father-of-five, who wore a dark blue suit, light blue shirt and white shirt, also pleaded guilty to possessing 12 Category B images and 22 Category C images.\n\nHowever, there were two moving images of a young child believed to be between 7 and 9 years old, prosecutors said.\n\nEdwards -- who remained the national broadcaster's top-earning news anchor even after he quit in disgrace -- confirmed his name, address, and date of birth in a loud clear voice ahead of the 26-minute hearing.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards and another adult man -- who was not identified -- had been messaging via WhatsApp between Dec. 2020 and Aug. 2021.\n\nDuring that time, Edwards received a total of 377 sexual images, 41 of which were indecent images of minors -- the bulk of which was sent in a two-month period.\n\nIn Feb. 2021, the man asked Edwards whether the minors in the images he was sending were too young, to which the disgraced anchor responded by telling him not to send anything illegal.\n\nThe two men continued to exchange pornographic material until April 2022, the court heard.\n\nEdwards' defense lawyer, Philip Evans KC, said there was no suggestion that the ex-BBC presenter had made or created any of the images.\n\nEvans added that Edwards did not keep or send the images on his device.\n\n\"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort,\" he told the court Wednesday.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\"\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat,\" he continued.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else, and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nAccording to the UK's Crown Prosecution Service, the term \"making\" can include opening, accessing, downloading and storing the content on a device.\n\nIt comes less than a week after the BBC published their annual report, in which salaries and earnings of the network's top employees were revealed.\n\nEdwards, who topped the list for newsreaders at the corporation with a staggering $616,000 annual salary, earned a massive $51,000 pay raise last year -- despite being suspended for most of that time.\n\nThe Welsh anchor was unmasked by his wife Vicky Flind last He later resigned for health reasons.\n\nThe offenses that he pleaded guilty to at Westminster Magistrates' Court in central London involved images shared on WhatsApp.\n\nAfter admitting the charges, He was formally charged June 26, following the Crown Prosecution Service's approval, the outlet reported. He was released on bail and is set to appear before the Westminster Magistrates' Court on July 31, according to Deadline.\n\n\"Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case,\" the MP's statement reportedly read. \"Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nU.K. law defines a 'child' as being a person under the age of 18, and defines \"making\" indecent images to mean opening an online attachment with an image, downloading an image onto a computer via a website, obtaining images of children through social media platforms or live-streaming such images, according to the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\nEdwards reportedly faces as much as 10 years behind bars, if convicted on all charges. pleas, Edwards sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards, and adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2, 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nRECOMMENDED READING:\n\nNo more were The veteran broadcaster, 62, who left the corporation in April, faces three charges over alleged activity between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nHe is due in court on Wednesday. According to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978. They carry a maximum penalty of 10 years' imprisonment.\n\nA police spokesperson said: \"Huw Edwards, 62, of Southwark, London, has been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children following a Met Police investigation. The offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Edwards was arrested on November 8 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, June 26, following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service. He has been bailed to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, July 31.\n\n\"Media and the public are strongly reminded that this is an active case. Nothing should be published, including on social media, which could prejudice future court proceedings.\"\n\nEdwards was one of the BBC's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors before he left the corporation earlier this year. During his career, he fronted BBC's News At Ten for 20 years and anchored coverage of major national events including announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe also helmed the BBC's broadcast of the King's coronation last year. Throughout the years he presented the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Cambridge (now the Prince and Princess of Wales) in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of Philip, Duke of Edinburgh, in 2021.\n\nThe BBC News At Ten presenter was also the broadcaster's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance and took over election coverage from the long-serving David Dimbleby in 2019. Before he stepped down, he was the BBC's highest-paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One news specials, election were sent to Edwards between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\n\"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort,\" Edwards' barrister, Philip Evans, said.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else, and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nUnder English law, the term 'making' also encompasses opening, accessing, downloading and storing illegal images.\n\nUntil recently, Edwards was one of {"uri": "8252157753", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:37:33", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:37:33Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:36:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6666666865348816, "url": "https://www.independent.co.uk/news/uk/crime/huw-edwards-indecent-images-children-court-bbc-b2588701.html", "title": "Huw Edwards pleads guilty to making indecent images of children", "body": "Appearing at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, the 62-year-old admitted three offences between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nDressed in a navy-blue suit and wearing dark sunglasses, Edwards arrived surrounded by a police escort to chaotic scenes, with protesters shouting as he made his way through the media scrum into the building.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster had 41 photographs on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nEdwards was emotionless after pleading guilty to the charges and sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was age between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nIn a statement, the Metropolitan Police said he was arrested in November last year and charged on June 26.\n\nEdwards, who was one of the BBC's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors before he left the corporation in April on medical grounds, could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years' imprisonment.\n\nDuring his career, he fronted BBC's News At Ten for 20 years and anchored coverage of major national events including announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe was previously the BBC's highest-paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 to \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for 160 presenting days, BBC One "sim": 0.6627451181411743, "url": "https://www.bridportnews.co.uk/news/national/24488054.ex-bbc-presenter-huw-edwards-admits-images-children-young-seven/", "title": "Ex-BBC presenter Huw Edwards admits having images of children as young as seven", "body": "Westminster Magistrates' Court was told seven of the 41 indecent images sent to the veteran broadcaster by the unnamed male were of the most serious type.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy, with the man telling the newsreader the child was \"quite young looking\" and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told in a 26-minute hearing.\n\nHe appeared nervous, fidgeting with his hands as Chief Magistrate Paul Goldspring told him he would not be sentencing him on Wednesday.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021, the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, to which Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nNo more indecent images more were sent after August 2021, but the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nSpeaking in Edwards' defence, his barrister Philip Evans KC said: \"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort.\n\n\"It is important also to remember for context that devices, Mr Edwards' devices, have been seized, have been searched, and there's nothing in those devices.\n\n\"It is only the images that are the subject of the charges that came via a WhatsApp chat.\n\n\"Mr Edwards did not keep any images, did not send any to anyone else and did not and has not sought similar images from anywhere else.\"\n\nMr Evans said the defendant had \"both mental and physical\" health issues.\n\nHe told the court: \"It is obvious to the court, I'm sure, that Mr Edwards was not just of good character, but of exceptional character.\"\n\nThe broadcaster was emotionless as he pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nAfter admitting the charges, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards.\n\nHe adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nMr Hope told the court that a suspended sentence might be considered for Edwards.\n\nSetting out the potential penalties under the law, he said that where there is the prospect of rehabilitation a community order and sexual offender treatment programme could be considered as alternatives to a custodial sentence.\n\nSentencing guidelines set the starting point for any jail term for possession of a Category A image at 12 months, with a range of 26 weeks to three years.\n\nThe starting point is 26 weeks for a category B image, and a community order for category C, he said.\n\nAggravating features to be taken into account for Edwards include that the images included moving images, and the young age of the child thought to be seven to nine years old in two of the category A images.\n\nMitigating factors are Edwards' early guilty plea, his previous good character, his mental health issues and what Mr Hope said is \"genuine remorse\".\n\nHe faced a barrage of cameras and photographers as he left court, but made no comment as he departed in a black Mercedes with tinted windows.\n\nClaire Brinton, from the Crown Prosecution Service (CPS), said: \"Accessing indecent images of underage people perpetuates the sexual exploitation of children, which has deep, long-lasting trauma on these victims.\n\n\"The CPS and the Metropolitan Police were able to prove that Edwards was receiving illegal material involving children via WhatsApp.\n\n\"This prosecution sends a clear message that the CPS, working alongside with the police, will work to bring to justice those who seek to exploit children, wherever that abuse takes place.\"\n\nEdwards will be appear at the same court again on September 16.", "source": {"uri": "bridportnews.co.uk", "dataType": "sim": 0.6549019813537598, "url": "https://today.rtl.lu/news/world/a/2218952.html", "title": "Ex-BBC presenter Edwards pleads guilty to indecent child images charges", "body": "Former BBC news anchor Huw Edwards, one of the most recognisable faces on UK television, pleaded guilty Wednesday to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nThe 62-year-old -- who resigned from the BBC in April on \"medical advice\", six months after he was arrested -- faces a maximum prison sentence of 10 years and a minimum of 12 months.\n\nWearing a dark suit and blue tie, Edwards sat impassively during the 25-minute court hearing as he admitted receiving 41 indecent images of children on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nUnder English law, electronic communications involving indecent imagery of children -- including receiving and downloading pictures and videos -- can constitute the offence of making indecent images of children.\n\nThe crimes involving Edwards occurred between December 2020 and August 2021, amended from the initial chargesheet which ran to April 2022.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court in London heard that the former TV anchor had received 377 sexual images from a man he met online, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\n\"These images appear to have been received with approval,\" prosecutor Ian Hope told the court.\n\nOf the gravest, the estimated age of most of the children was 13 to 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, he noted.\n\nEdwards had been told that the male in the \"moving film\" was \"quite young looking\" and that he could be sent more that were \"illegal\".\n\nAlthough the ex-presenter received that film, he told the man not to send any illegal images, the court heard.\n\n- 'Serious issues' -\n\nEdwards's lawyer, Philip Evans, said that his client's devices had been seized and that it was clear he had not made or shared the images.\n\n\"There's no suggestion in this case that Mr Edwards has... in the traditional sense of the word, created any image of any sort,\" Evans told the court.\n\nHe added that the defendant was of \"good character\" and that \"there are serious issues in relation to Mr Edwards's health both mental and physical\".\n\nChief magistrate Paul Goldspring released Edwards on conditional bail until his next hearing on September 16, when he could be sentenced.\n\nGoldspring ordered probation services to draw up a report, telling Edwards he needed \"to read more about you\" before sentencing.\n\n\"I'm asking the probation service to look at this case, with genuinely all options open,\" the magistrate said.\n\nHope had earlier told the court that a suspended sentence might be appropriate, if paired with a community order and a sexual offender treatment programme.\n\nEdwards, the BBC's lead presenter on key events such as the death and funeral of Queen Elizabeth II, was suspended in July 2023 when allegations first emerged.\n\nHe had also been the anchor of the BBC's flagship 10:00 pm news programme since 2003.\n\nHe quit on April 22 after 40 years with the broadcaster.\n\nAs the accusations became front-page news last July, Edwards's wife Vicky Flind said the father of five was \"suffering from serious mental health issues\" and had been admitted to hospital.\n\nEdwards himself has not publicly commented on the allegations.\n\nThe BBC's brand has been built on public trust but the broadcaster has been rocked in recent years by scandals which saw some big names revealed as serial sex offenders.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8252187368", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:56:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:56:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:56:04Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6431372761726379, "url": "https://www.dailypost.co.uk/news/north-wales-news/ex-bbc-presenter-huw-edwards-29648046", "title": "Ex-BBC presenter Huw Edwards admits having indecent images of children", "body": "Former BBC presenter Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to three offences of making indecent images of children. The veteran broadcaster admitted having 41 on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type. Westminster Magistrates' Court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nWearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, the 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday, reports PA.\n\nAfter entering his pleas, Edwards sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards, and adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nREAD MORE: Financial services worker stole \u00a375,000 from estates of dead people to fund gambling addiction\n\nREAD MORE: Woman breathalysed in Lidl car park nearly five times over drink drive limit\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2, 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C. Of the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told. The final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal. The veteran broadcaster admitted having 41 on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021. Wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, the 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday.\n\nHe was emotionless as he pleaded guilty. After admitting the charges, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards. He adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2, 2021, the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard. The indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was age between seven and nine, the court was told. The final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young-looking and that he had more images which were illegal. Mr Edwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told. No more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.\n\nMore follows.", "source": {"uri": "cornwalllive.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Cornwall admitted to making indecent images of children.\n\nHe was the BBC's highest paid newsreader and presented the News At Ten for decades but his guilty plea marks the apparent end of a glittering career.\n\nEdwards was regarded as the best known face of BBC News and was seen as a safe pair of hands to guide the country through major events.\n\nHuw Edwards (Dominic Lipinski/PA)\n\nHowever he is now making headlines himself as he admitted having 41 images on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nThe 62-year-old fronted the flagship nightly news programme for the last 20 years, earning a reputation as a respected veteran broadcaster, before he resigned from the corporation in April.\n\nOn Wednesday, he pleaded guilty at Westminster Magistrates' Court to making indecent images of children between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nBorn in Bridgend and brought up in Llangennech, Carmarthenshire, Edwards joined the BBC as a trainee in 1984.\n\nDuring his four decades at the corporation, he was chosen over and over again to front the coverage of the major news of the day, leading coverage of historic events including the late Queen's funeral in 2022 and most recently the coronation of the King in May 2023.\n\nEdwards also announced the late Queen's death on the BBC in September 2022.\n\nHe was front and centre in live broadcasts of election coverage, the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the then Duke and Duchess of Cambridge in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of the Duke of Edinburgh in 2021.\n\nEdwards was also the BBC's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance.\n\nWhen the BBC was looking for someone to take over election coverage from the long-serving David Dimbleby in 2019, it was Edwards who was chosen.\n\nEdwards announced the late Queen\u00b4s death on the BBC in September 2022 (PA)\n\nEdwards was also the corporation's highest paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24, before he resigned, according to the BBC's latest annual report.\n\nThis last salary marked an increase from 2022/23, when he was paid between \u00a3435,000 and 439,999 for 180 days presenting on BBC One, as well as news specials.\n\nIn 2018, it was reported he agreed to take a pay cut following revelations over unequal pay for men and women at the BBC.\n\nEdwards said in 2021 that he was considering his future presenting News At Ten as he approached his 60th birthday.\n\nThe broadcaster, who attended Llanelli Grammar School and graduated in French from Cardiff University, is an honorary professor in the School of Journalism, Media and Culture at his old university.\n\nIn June 2023, Edwards picked up the best live event honour at the Tric Awards for being among those to cover the state funeral of the late Queen, and in February he received the Broadcast Awards' special recognition award.\n\nEdwards is listed as a vice president on the website of the National Churches Trust and has appeared on Songs Of Praise.\n\nHe has also made documentaries for the BBC including Wales: Who Do We Think We Are? and talked about his depression on S4C's Huw Edwards Is 60.\n\nFormer BBC broadcaster Huw Edwards arriving at Westminster Magistrates\u00b4 Court (Aaron Chown/PA)\n\nIn a documentary in 2021, Edwards revealed he has had bouts of depression over the last two decades which have left him \"bedridden\".\n\n\"Like everyone that suffers with depression, you don't get one bout of it. It comes and goes,\" he said.\n\n\"For me, it started around 2002 I think. I went down fairly quickly and I couldn't understand it.\"\n\nSpeaking on a podcast hosted by Jane Garvey and Fi Glover, Fortunately... With Fi And Jane, Edwards said he decided to share publicly that he has depression as he felt it was \"complete hypocrisy\" to support organisations such as the Shawmind Foundation or Mind without explaining why.\n\n\"I also felt that it might be someway helpful to people if I opened up about it and say, 'You can do a job and you can be successful', whether it's just reading a bit of autocue or admits having indecent images of children", "body": "The veteran broadcaster appeared at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.\n\nFormer BBC presenter Huw Edwards has pleaded guilty to making indecent images of children.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster admitted having 41 on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nWearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, the 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday.\n\nAfter entering his pleas, Edwards sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards, and adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nNo more They were investigated separately as a standalone case,\" a police spokesperson said.\n\nMr Edwards left the BBC in April. He was previously the corporation's most high-profile and best-paid news anchor, one of the main presenters on BBC One's Ten O'Clock News, and was often chosen to front coverage of major national events.\n\nHe was previously the BBC's highest-paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 to \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24 for just 160 presenting days, according to the BBC's latest It will be quite a moment when he appears in Westminster magistrates' court on Wednesday morning,\" a source told The Times.\n\nHe is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp, according to the chargesheet.\n\nPolice said Edwards was arrested on 8 November last year and charged on 26 June this year following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\nThe offences are claimed to be linked to images shared on WhatsApp, police said. If found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of six months in prison and an unlimited fine. The BBC declined to comment.\n\nIt comes less than a week after it was revealed Edwards was the third highest paid journalist at the corporation and received a \u00a340,000 pay rise last year, despite being suspended for most of that time.\n\nEdwards earned between \u00a3475,000-\u00a3479,999, up from \u00a3435,000-\u00a3439,999 in the previous year, the corporation's annual report said.\n\nThe BBC's director general Tim Davie said the pay rise was due to the BBC trying to act \"proportionally\".\n\n\"I think that's what we did and it ended up in the conclusion, we all know, but I think we The broadcaster admitted having 41 on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021. Wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, the 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday.\n\nAfter entering his pleas, Edwards sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards, and adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nREAD MORE: Devastated parents are 'not speaking, only crying' after little girl, 9, killed in Southport stabbing\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard. The indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told. The final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal. Edwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told. More info\n\nFormer BBC presenter Huw Edwards has arrived at court one year after he was charged with making indecent images of children.\n\nThe 62-year-old is alleged to have committed the three offences between December 2020 and April 2022. The veteran broadcaster is accused of having had 37 photographs on WhatsApp, including six of the most serious type.\n\nHe was swarmed by photographers as he arrived at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday morning, and refused to answer any questions. Photographers were knocked to the ground as they scrambled to get to the broadcaster.\n\nHe arrived wearing black sunglasses, a blue tie, white shirt and black suit.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp - offences contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978.\n\nThe images are alleged to have been shared via WhatsApp.\n\nIf found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years' imprisonment.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police said he was arrested in {"uri": "8252364448", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "11:38:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T11:38:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T11:36:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.irvinetimes.com/news/national/24488056.huw-edwards-guilty-plea-marks-fall-grace-veteran-ex-bbc-broadcaster/", "title": "Huw Edwards: Guilty plea marks fall from grace for veteran ex-BBC broadcaster", "body": "One of the most recognisable faces on British television, Huw Edwards anchored coverage of major national events before his public downfall as he admitted making indecent images of children.\n\nHe was the BBC's highest-paid newsreader and presented the News At Ten for decades but his guilty plea marks the apparent end of a glittering career.\n\nEdwards was regarded as the best-known face of BBC News and was seen as a safe pair of hands to guide the country through major events.\n\nHowever he is now making headlines himself after admitting having 41 images on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nThe 62-year-old fronted the flagship nightly news programme for the last 20 years, earning a reputation as a respected veteran broadcaster, before he resigned from the corporation in April.\n\nOn Wednesday, he pleaded guilty at Westminster Magistrates' Court to making indecent images of children between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nBorn in Bridgend and brought up in Llangennech, Carmarthenshire, Edwards joined the BBC as a trainee in 1984.\n\nDuring his four decades at the corporation, he was chosen over and over again to front the coverage of the major news of the day, leading coverage of historic events including the late Queen's funeral in 2022 and most recently the coronation of the King in May 2023.\n\nEdwards also announced the late Queen's death on the BBC in September 2022.\n\nHe was front and centre in live broadcasts of election coverage, the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the then Duke and Duchess of Cambridge in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of the Duke of Edinburgh in 2021.\n\nEdwards was also the BBC's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance.\n\nWhen the BBC was looking for someone to take over election coverage from the long-serving David Dimbleby in 2019, it was Edwards who was chosen.\n\nEdwards was also the corporation's highest-paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 to \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24, before he resigned, according to the BBC's latest annual report.\n\nThis last salary marked an increase from 2022/23, when he was paid between \u00a3435,000 and \u00a3439,999 for 180 days presenting on BBC One, as well as news specials.\n\nIn 2018, it was reported that he had agreed to take a pay cut following revelations over unequal pay for men and women at the BBC.\n\nEdwards said in 2021 that he was considering his future presenting News At Ten as he approached his 60th birthday.\n\nThe broadcaster, who attended Llanelli Grammar School and graduated in French from Cardiff University, is an honorary professor in the School of Journalism, Media and Culture at his old university.\n\nIn June 2023, Edwards picked up the best live event honour at the Tric Awards for being among those to cover the state funeral of the late Queen, and in February he received the Broadcast Awards' special recognition award.\n\nEdwards was previously a vice president of the National Churches Trust and has appeared on Songs Of Praise.\n\nAfter news of the charges emerged, the Trust said in a statement: \"In light of the news on 29 July, the National Churches Trust has confirmed that Huw Edwards is no longer a vice president for the charity. We are shocked and saddened by the recent developments.\"\n\nEdwards also made documentaries for the BBC including Wales: Who Do We Think We Are? and talked about his depression on S4C's Huw Edwards Is 60.\n\nIn a documentary in 2021, Edwards revealed he has had bouts of depression over the last two decades which have left him \"bedridden\".\n\n\"Like everyone that suffers with depression, you don't get one bout of it. It comes and goes,\" he said.\n\n\"For me, it started around 2002 I think. I went down fairly quickly and I couldn't understand it.\"\n\nSpeaking on a podcast hosted by Jane Garvey and Fi Glover, Fortunately... With Fi And Jane, Edwards said he decided to share publicly that he has depression as he felt it was \"complete hypocrisy\" to support organisations such as the Shawmind Foundation or Mind without explaining why.\n\n\"I also felt that it might be someway helpful to people if I opened up about it and say 'You can do a job and you can be successful', whether it's just reading a bit of autocue or doing whatever it is... while also dealing with issues like that,\" he told the podcast.", "source": {"uri": "irvinetimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Irvine Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": He is often referred to as the \"face of historic events\" due to his role as a newsreader and presenter for major events and significant moments in British history.\n\nBorn on August 18, 1961, in Bridgend, Wales, Huw Edwards joined the BBC in 1984 as a news trainee and quickly rose through the ranks. He became a regular presenter on BBC News and has since become one of the most recognisable and respected newsreaders in the United Kingdom.\n\nAlso Read | Alarming warning from WHO: Bird flu poses increased risk of adapting to humans\n\nHuw Edwards is also known for his calm and authoritative delivery style, which has made him a trusted figure in broadcasting. He has covered numerous important events, including elections, royal weddings, state funerals, and major national and international news stories.\n\nIn addition to news reading, Huw Edwards has presented several BBC programmes, including the documentary series \"The Story of Wales.\" He has also been involved in the coverage of significant events such as the Olympic Games and the Proms, a renowned classical music festival in the UK.\n\nAlso Read | India backs Pakistan's resolution at UN condemning Quran burning protests\n\nMost recently before the sex scandal row, Huw Edwards was a prominent figure on the BBC, serving as the main presenter of the BBC News at Ten, the network's flagship evening news programme. In 2017, when the BBC was required by the parliament to disclose the salaries of its top presenters, it was revealed that Edwards earned \u00a3550,000 ($716,023). Due to public scrutiny over the BBC's expenditure on talent and the gender pay gap among its stars, Edwards decided to take a pay cut.\n\nDuring an interview with BBC Radio Cymru in 2021, Edwards hinted that his tenure as the BBC's chief news anchor may be coming to an end due to the demands of the role.\n\n\"The nightly news business, after 20 years, that can be taxing, even though I still enjoy the job,\" he said. \"But I don't think I'll be doing that for long... {"uri": "2024-07-439282924", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:14:24", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:14:24Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:00:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5843137502670288, "url": "https://ca.style.yahoo.com/huw-edwards-arrives-court-being-090052048.html", "title": "Huw Edwards arrives in court after being charged with making indecent images of children", "body": "Huw Edwards has arrived at court after being charged with making indecent images of children. The former BBC newsreader arrived at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday morning in a dark blue suit while wearing sunglasses.\n\nThe TV personality, who left the BBC on medical advice in 2023, had a neutral expression as police helped him through the crowd of photographers and crowds holding placards and into the courtroom.\n\nHuw has been charged with making indecent images of children. He has been accused of having 37 photographs on WhatsApp; six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs, with category A being the most serious type.\n\nThe 62-year-old was arrested in November 2023 and charged on 26 June. It has since been reported that he has split from his wife Vicky Flind following the arrest. According to the Independent, it is understood that the pair have not divorced, but are living apart.\n\nShe released a statement to the press following the initial report from The Sun that claimed that Huw had been paying a teenager for photos. He is set to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.\n\nWho is Huw Edwards?\n\nHuw Edwards has been a television journalist for 30 years, primarily known for presenting BBC News at Ten, Britain's most-watched news programme. He grew up in Llangennech, Carmarthenshire, and attended Llanelli Grammar School before pursuing higher education. Currently, he lives in London with his wife and five children. Huw Edwards graduated from Cardiff University with a degree in French. He also holds honorary fellowships from Cardiff University, Swansea University and the University of Wales, Lampeter, and an honorary doctorate from the University of Glamorgan. Edwards has anchored coverage of significant events, including the London 2012 Olympic Games, the Royal Wedding (for which he received a BAFTA for Best Coverage of a Live Event), and the inauguration of US President Barack Obama. He left the BBC in April this year.He has also presented numerous programmes on history and classical music across various BBC channels. His documentaries have covered significant historical figures such as David Lloyd George, Gladstone, Disraeli and Owain Glyndwr. start of the hearing on Wednesday.\n\nAfter entering his pleas, Edwards sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards, and adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nThe bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2 2021 the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard.\n\nThe indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nThe final indecent image was sent in August 2021, a category A film featuring a young boy.\n\nThe man told Edwards that the boy was quite young looking, and that he had more images which were illegal.\n\nEdwards told him not to send any illegal images, the court was told.\n\nNo more were sent, and the pair continued to exchange legal pornographic images until April 2022.", "source": {"uri": "glasgowtimes.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Glasgow Times"},
