{"uri": "8252259808", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:40:15", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:40:15Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:38:20Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5764706134796143, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/huw-edwards-guilty-plea-marks-103627038.html", "title": "Huw Edwards: Guilty plea marks fall from grace for veteran ex-BBC broadcaster", "body": "One of the most recognisable faces on British television, Huw Edwards anchored coverage of major national events before his public downfall as he admitted to making indecent images of children.\n\nHe was the BBC's highest paid newsreader and presented the News At Ten for decades but his guilty plea marks the apparent end of a glittering career.\n\nEdwards was regarded as the best known face of BBC News and was seen as a safe pair of hands to guide the country through major events.\n\nHowever he is now making headlines himself as he admitted having 41 images on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nThe 62-year-old fronted the flagship nightly news programme for the last 20 years, earning a reputation as a respected veteran broadcaster, before he resigned from the corporation in April.\n\nOn Wednesday, he pleaded guilty at Westminster Magistrates' Court to making indecent images of children between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nBorn in Bridgend and brought up in Llangennech, Carmarthenshire, Edwards joined the BBC as a trainee in 1984.\n\nDuring his four decades at the corporation, he was chosen over and over again to front the coverage of the major news of the day, leading coverage of historic events including the late Queen's funeral in 2022 and most recently the coronation of the King in May 2023.\n\nEdwards also announced the late Queen's death on the BBC in September 2022.\n\nHe was front and centre in live broadcasts of election coverage, the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the then Duke and Duchess of Cambridge in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of the Duke of Edinburgh in 2021.\n\nEdwards was also the BBC's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance.\n\nWhen the BBC was looking for someone to take over election coverage from the long-serving David Dimbleby in 2019, it was Edwards who was chosen.\n\nEdwards was also the corporation's highest paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 and \u00a3479,999 for the year 2023/24, before he resigned, according to the BBC's latest annual report.\n\nThis last salary marked an increase from 2022/23, when he was paid between \u00a3435,000 and 439,999 for 180 days presenting on BBC One, as well as news specials.\n\nIn 2018, it was reported he agreed to take a pay cut following revelations over unequal pay for men and women at the BBC.\n\nEdwards said in 2021 that he was considering his future presenting News At Ten as he approached his 60th birthday.\n\nThe broadcaster, who attended Llanelli Grammar School and graduated in French from Cardiff University, is an honorary professor in the School of Journalism, Media and Culture at his old university.\n\nIn June 2023, Edwards picked up the best live event honour at the Tric Awards for being among those to cover the state funeral of the late Queen, and in February he received the Broadcast Awards' special recognition award.\n\nEdwards is listed as a vice president on the website of the National Churches Trust and has appeared on Songs Of Praise.\n\nHe has also made documentaries for the BBC including Wales: Who Do We Think We Are? and talked about his depression on S4C's Huw Edwards Is 60.\n\nIn a documentary in 2021, Edwards revealed he has had bouts of depression over the last two decades which have left him \"bedridden\".\n\n\"Like everyone that suffers with depression, you don't get one bout of it. It comes and goes,\" he said.\n\n\"For me, it started around 2002 I think. I went down fairly quickly and I couldn't understand it.\"\n\nSpeaking on a podcast hosted by Jane Garvey and Fi Glover, Fortunately... With Fi And Jane, Edwards said he decided to share publicly that he has depression as he felt it was \"complete hypocrisy\" to support organisations such as the Shawmind Foundation or Mind without explaining why.\n\n\"I also felt that it might be someway helpful to people if I opened up about it and say, 'You can do a job and you can be successful', whether it's just reading a bit of autocue or The veteran broadcaster admitted having 41 on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court heard the offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021. Wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses, the 62-year-old spoke to confirm his name, date of birth, address and his guilty pleas at the start of the hearing on Wednesday.\n\nHe was emotionless as he pleaded guilty. After admitting the charges, he sat staring into the distance, with his head tilted slightly upwards. He adjusted his tie as Ian Hope, prosecuting, laid out the case against him.\n\nThe court heard that Edwards had been involved in online chat with an adult man on WhatsApp between December 2020 and August 2021, who sent him 377 sexual images, of which 41 were indecent images of children. The bulk of these, 36, were sent during a two-month period.\n\nOn February 2, 2021, the male asked whether what he was sending was too young, in response to which Mr Edwards told him not to send any underage images, the court heard. The indecent images that were sent included seven category A, the worst, 12 category B, and 22 category C.\n\nOf the category A images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, {"uri": "8252220627", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:16:18", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:16:18Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:15:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.572549045085907, "url": "https://www.irishmirror.ie/showbiz/celebrity-news/huw-edwards-marriage-vicky-flind-33364952", "title": "Inside Huw Edward's marriage - religion, five kids and 'decision to split'", "body": "Huw Edwards reportedly moved out of his marital home a while ago after splitting from his wife Vicky Flind.\n\nThe former BBC News presenter, 62, entered guilty pleas to all charges against him at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday after being charged with three counts of making indecent images of children. It is the first time the Welsh journalist has been seen publicly since July 2023. He was arrested in November 2023 and officially resigned from the BBC in April 2024.\n\nThe offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat. Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B images and 19 category C images. If found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine.\n\nREAD MORE: Huw Edwards pleads guilty to all child sex offence charges against him\n\nREAD MORE: Prince William and Prince Harry suffer heart-breaking loss as uncle dies\n\nEdwards is best known for presenting the Six O'Clock News and was a key reporter at Prince William and Kate Middleton's wedding. He also announced Queen Elizabeth's death in 2022 and led the BBC's coverage of her funeral.\n\nEdwards is now said to have moved out of his family home in Dulwich, south London, after reportedly separating from his wife Vicky, 62. It is believed he has moved to another property in the capital and has been splitting his time between there and his native Wales. The former couple have reportedly not yet divorced. They share five grown-up children - three sons and two daughters.\n\nA source told The Sun: \"They separated quite a long time ago but have not announced it publicly. Huw has been living elsewhere for a while.\" Vicky also works in television and was previously the editor of the BBC's This Week before she moved to ITV's rival politics show, Peston, while she also worked on Britain's Next Prime Minister.\n\nThe pair are said to have met when Huw was working as a BBC correspondent in Westminster and got engaged in 1993. It was Vicky who named Huw as the man at the centre of the allegations last year in a statement issued on his behalf. She detailed his \"serious mental health issues\" and said: \"I am doing this primarily out of concern for his mental well-being and to protect our children.\"\n\nEdwards once spoke about his relationship with his kids and how he 'cracked the code' of parenting with his fifth. He told The Guardian : \"There's a principle that your youngest child gets a far better crack of the whip than your eldest.\n\n\"All your anxieties and inexperience and cluelessness as a parent are taken out on your eldest child. By the time you get to your youngest, in my case number five, you're a brilliant parent. So if you could give a parent all the patience and knowledge that they would have with their second or third child or whatever to the first, that's the one piece of advice I'd give.\"\n\nHe was passionate about teaching his children how to speak Welsh, despite his wife not speaking the language. He previously told Wales Online : \"I was able to concentrate a lot of time on my eldest two children who have got a good level of understanding in Welsh but the others less so. Three of my sons are linguists actually and I've got a daughter who is a linguist.\n\n\"Their facility to speak, pronounce and understand, it's quite good but what you won't get is a fluent conversation... They talk frequently to my mum who is back in Llanelli and they are very aware of the heritage of my dad and the fact he was such a big figure in Welsh language culture and are very proud of that.\"\n\nEdwards' father was a prominent Welsh nationalist and historian who passed away in 2010. Speaking about his turbulent relationship in a S4C documentary, Edwards said: \"We weren't that close, to be honest - not like me and mam, because dad wasn't that present when I was growing up. He could be quite sharp.\n\n\"I laugh when people tell me that Dad was full of humour and that he always had a smile on his face. I often think - what, do you live on the same planet as me? Yes, he could be very witty and he could laugh. He could be very sharp-tongued at times and if you were on the receiving end of that, it wasn't very fun.\"\n\nHuw is a religious man and devoted Christian and has always gone to church weekly to practise his faith. He was previously the Vice President of the National Churches Trust and told Sorted Magazine last year that churches \"have a vital role to play in moments of national importance; bringing people together, providing quiet spaces for reflection and prayer, and places for communities to gather and share\".\n\nBut on Tuesday, Edwards was stripped of his role at the trust. The charity, which supports the UK's churches to maintain their historic sites and buildings, said in a statement: \"In light of the news yesterday, the National Churches Trust has confirmed that Huw Edwards is no longer a Vice President for the charity. We are shocked and saddened by the recent developments.\"\n\nJoin the Irish Mirror's breaking news service on WhatsApp. Click this link to receive breaking news and the latest headlines direct to your phone. "title": "Ex-BBC presenter Huw Edwards arrives at court to face indecent images charges", "body": "The 62-year-old is alleged to have committed three offences between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nThe veteran broadcaster is accused of having had 37 photographs on WhatsApp, including six of the most serious type.\n\nEdwards arrived at Westminster Magistrates' Court shortly before 9.15am on Wednesday wearing a dark suit, blue tie and sunglasses.\n\nHe refused to answer any questions from the journalists present.\n\nPhotographers were knocked to the ground as they scrambled to get to the broadcaster as he entered the court building flanked by police officers.\n\nThe Metropolitan Police said he was arrested in November last year and charged on June 26.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp - offences contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978.\n\nThe images are alleged to have been shared via WhatsApp.\n\nIf found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years in prison.\n\nEdwards was one of the BBC's most prominent and highest-paid news anchors before he left the corporation in April on medical grounds.\n\nDuring his career, he fronted BBC's News At Ten for 20 years and anchored coverage of major national events including announcing Queen Elizabeth II's death on the BBC and presenting coverage of her funeral.\n\nHe was previously the BBC's highest-paid newsreader, with a pay bracket of \u00a3475,000 to {"uri": "8252174038", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "09:48:20", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T09:48:20Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T09:47:21Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.mirror.co.uk/news/uk-news/inside-huw-edwards-marriage-wife-33363589", "title": "Inside Huw Edward's marriage - religion, five kids and 'decision to split'", "body": "Ex-BBC News anchor Huw Edwards, who today entered guilty pleas to all child sex offence charges against him, has reportedly split from his wife Vicky Flind and moved out of their home\n\nHuw Edwards reportedly moved out of his marital home a while ago after splitting from his wife Vicky Flind.\n\nThe former BBC News presenter, 62, entered guilty pleas to all charges against him at Westminster Magistrates' Court today, after being charged with three counts of making indecent images of children. It is the first time the Welsh journalist has been seen publicly since July 2023. He was arrested in November 2023 and officially resigned from the BBC in April 2024.\n\nThe offences, which are alleged to have taken place between December 2020 and April 2022, relate to images shared on a WhatsApp chat. Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B images and 19 category C images. If found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of 10 years imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine.\n\nEdwards is best known for presenting the Six O'Clock News and was a key reporter at Prince William and Kate Middleton's wedding. He also announced Queen Elizabeth's death in 2022 and led the BBC's coverage of her funeral.\n\nEdwards is now said to have moved out of his family home in Dulwich, south London, after reportedly separating from his wife Vicky, 62. It is believed he has moved to another property in the capital and has been splitting his time between there and his native Wales. The former couple have reportedly not yet divorced. They share five grown-up children - three sons and two daughters.\n\nA source told The Sun: \"They separated quite a long time ago but have not announced it publicly. Huw has been living elsewhere for a while.\" Vicky also works in television and was previously the editor of the BBC's This Week before she moved to ITV's rival politics show Peston, while she also worked on Britain's Next Prime Minister.\n\nThe pair are said to have met when Huw was working as a BBC correspondent in Westminster and got engaged in 1993. It was Vicky who named Huw as the man at the centre of the allegations last year in a statement issued on his behalf. She detailed his \"serious mental health issues\" and said: \"I am doing this primarily out of concern for his mental well-being and to protect our children.\"\n\nEdwards once spoke about his relationship with his kids and how he 'cracked the code' of parenting with his fifth. He told The Guardian: \"There's a principle that your youngest child gets a far better crack of the whip than your eldest.\n\n\"All your anxieties and inexperience and cluelessness as a parent are taken out on your eldest child. By the time you get to your youngest, in my case number five, you're a brilliant parent. So if you could give a parent all the patience and knowledge that they would have with their second or third child or whatever to the first, that's the one piece of advice I'd give.\"\n\nHe was passionate about teaching his children how to speak Welsh, despite his wife not speaking the language. He previously told Wales Online: \"I was able to concentrate a lot of time on my eldest two children who have got a good level of understanding in Welsh but the others less so. Three of my sons are linguists actually and I've got a daughter who is a linguist.\n\n\"Their facility to speak, pronounce and understand, it's quite good but what you won't get is a fluent conversation... They talk frequently to my mum who is back in Llanelli and they are very aware of the heritage of my dad and the fact he was such a big figure in Welsh language culture and are very proud of that.\"\n\nEdwards' father was a prominent Welsh nationalist and historian who passed away in 2010. Speaking about his turbulent relationship in a S4C documentary, Edwards said: \"We weren't that close, to be honest - not like me and mam, because dad wasn't that present when I was growing up. He could be quite sharp.\n\n\"I laugh when people tell me that Dad was full of humour and that he always had a smile on his face. I often think - what, do you live on the same planet as me? Yes, he could be very witty and he could laugh. He could be very sharp-tongued at times and if you were on the receiving end of that, it wasn't very fun.\"\n\nHuw is a religious man and devoted Christian and has always gone to church weekly to practise his faith. He was previously the Vice President of the National Churches Trust and told Sorted Magazine last year that churches \"have a vital role to play in moments of national importance; bringing people together, providing quiet spaces for reflection and prayer, and places for communities to gather and share\".\n\nBut on Tuesday, Edwards was stripped of his role at the trust. The charity, which supports the UK's churches to maintain their historic sites and buildings, said in a statement: \"In light of the news yesterday, the National Churches Trust has confirmed that Huw Edwards is no longer a Vice President for the charity. {"uri": "8252250492", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "10:33:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T10:33:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T10:33:02Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5607843399047852, "url": "https://www.ft.com/content/bd9fa2ba-3fe7-49c5-bc72-d81f5f993c27", "title": "Huw Edwards pleads guilty to making indecent images of children", "body": "Huw Edwards, the former BBC presenter, has pleaded guilty to possessing indecent images and videos of children as young as seven years old.\n\nThe 62-year-old, who was one of the public broadcaster's biggest stars, admitted to receiving about 40 such pictures and films on WhatsApp, including seven deemed to be Category A -- the most serious type.\n\nSitting alone in the dock and wearing a dark suit and blue tie, he answered \"guilty\" to each of three charges at the start of a hearing on Wednesday in central London.\n\nEdwards was the BBC's best-paid newsreader, who fronted the UK public broadcaster's flagship News at Ten programme and presented coverage of events of national importance including the state funeral of Queen Elizabeth.\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court heard that Edwards had engaged in an online chat with another individual on WhatsApp and had been sent scores of still and moving images.\n\nProsecutor Ian Hope said that 41 of these reached the threshold for criminality -- seven considered as Category A images, 12 as Category B and 22 as Category C.\n\nHope said that many of the Category A images were believed to be of a child aged between 13 and 15, while another was of a child possibly as young as seven.\n\nEdwards had asked the individual not to send illegal underage images, the court heard. {"uri": "2024-07-438589358", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-30", "time": "17:03:31", "dateTime": "2024-07-30T17:03:31Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-30T16:48:39Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.aol.co.uk/news/cps-accused-breaching-open-justice-164839958.html", "title": "CPS accused of breaching open justice principles in Huw Edwards case", "body": "CPS accused of breaching open justice principles in Huw Edwards case\n\nPatrick Sawer\n\n30 July 2024 at 6:48 pm\n\nThe Crown Prosecution Service has been criticised for breaching open justice principles by failing to release that Huw Edwards had been charged with three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nThe former BBC newsreader was charged in June, but the details only emerged on Monday, after the date of his first court appearance was published by Westminster Magistrates.\n\nOne prominent former attorney general said he found it \"very puzzling\" that the CPS had not released details of the charges brought against Mr Edwards around the time he had been charged.\n\nHe said the decision by the CPS not to reveal in June that it had charged Edwards appeared not to be \"in accordance with\" the principles of open justice.\n\nThe 62-year-old, who left the BBC last year, will appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday, charged with three offences relating to images shared on WhatsApp.\n\nEdwards, who was one of the BBC's most highly-paid stars, was arrested last November by detectives from Scotland Yard.\n\n'A public matter'\n\nThe former attorney general, who asked not to be named, told The Telegraph: \"It is very puzzling that the CPs did not release the charge details to the media.\n\n\"Normally, with high-profile cases, an announcement is made that charges have been brought. This notifies members of the media that a first court appearance is imminent to allow them to report on it, in accordance with the principles of open justice.\n\n\"I'm therefore puzzled that the CPS did not announce charges when they were brought in June, as at that point it became a public matter.\"\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp.\n\nThe offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978. If found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of six months imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine.\n\nThe CPS denied it had deliberately suppressed details about Edwards being charged or given him preferential treatment.\n\n'Approach taken isn't unusual'\n\nA CPS spokesperson said: \"Decisions on charging announcements are based on operational factors and no defendant receives preferential treatment.\n\n\"Our handling of this case followed our normal procedures working in partnership with police colleagues.\"\n\nScotland Yard denied it had taken a different approach in informing the media in the case of Edwards.\n\nA spokesman for the Metropolitan Police said: \"The approach taken in this case isn't unusual. Quite often when there is a lengthy gap between the date someone is charged and their first appearance we will publish the details immediately before the first appearance.\n\n\"The purpose of us releasing the details is to allow media to cover the court proceedings so providing it is prior to that date we have met that requirement.\n\n\"In this case, another media outlet spotted that the listings had gone up. Had nobody done so they would have been shared with media proactively today, ahead of tomorrow's hearing.\"\n\nEdwards was suspended by the BBC last July following media reports that a high-profile presenter had been involved in an inappropriate relationship with a young man.\n\nHis wife later confirmed he was the presenter at the centre of the allegations, adding that he was being treated for glittering career.\n\nEdwards was regarded as the best known face of BBC News and was seen as a safe pair of hands to guide the country through major events.\n\nThe 62-year-old fronted the flagship nightly news programme for the last 20 years, earning a reputation as a respected veteran broadcaster, before he resigned from the corporation in April.\n\nOn Wednesday, he pleaded guilty at Westminster Magistrates' Court to making indecent images of children between December 2020 and August 2021.\n\nBorn in Bridgend and brought up in Llangennech, Carmarthenshire, Edwards joined the BBC as a trainee in 1984.\n\nDuring his four decades at the corporation, he was chosen over and over again to front the coverage of the major news of the day, leading coverage of historic events including the late Queen's funeral in 2022 and most recently the coronation of the King in May 2023.\n\nEdwards also announced the late Queen's death on the BBC in September 2022.\n\nHe was front and centre in live broadcasts of election coverage, the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the then Duke and Duchess of Cambridge in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of the Duke of Edinburgh in 2021.\n\nEdwards was also the BBC's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance.\n\nWhen the BBC was looking for someone to take over election coverage from the long-serving David Dimbleby in 2019, it was Edwards who was chosen.\n\nThis last salary marked an increase from 2022/23, when he was paid between \u00a3435,000 and 439,999 for 180 days presenting on BBC One, as well as news specials.\n\nIn 2018, it was reported he agreed to take a pay cut following revelations over unequal pay for men and women at the BBC.\n\nEdwards said in 2021 that he was considering his future presenting News At Ten as he approached his 60th birthday.\n\nThe broadcaster, who attended Llanelli Grammar School and graduated in French from Cardiff University, is an honorary professor in the School of Journalism, Media and Culture at his old university.\n\nIn June 2023, Edwards picked up the best live event honour at the Tric Awards for being among those to cover the state funeral of the late Queen, and in February he received the Broadcast Awards' special recognition award.\n\nEdwards is listed as a vice president on the website of the National Churches Trust and has appeared on Songs Of Praise.\n\nHe has also made documentaries for the BBC including Wales: Who Do We Think We Are? and talked about his depression on S4C's Huw Edwards Is 60.\n\n\"Like everyone that suffers with depression, you don't get one bout of it. It comes and goes,\" he said.\n\n\"For me, it started around 2002 I think. I went down fairly quickly and I couldn't understand it.\"\n\nSpeaking on a podcast hosted by Jane Garvey and Fi Glover, Fortunately... With Fi And Jane, Edwards said he decided to share publicly that he has depression as he felt it was \"complete hypocrisy\" to support organisations such as the Shawmind Foundation or Mind without explaining why.\n\n\"I also felt that it might be someway helpful to people if I opened up about it and say, 'You can do a job and you can be successful', whether it's just reading a bit of autocue or doing whatever it is... while also dealing with issues like that,\" he told the podcast.", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Guernsey Press"}, "authors": [], The former BBC star was arrested on November 8 2023. He was charged on Wednesday, June 26 following authorisation from the Crown Prosecution Service.\n\nAccording to the charge sheet, Edwards is accused of having six category A images, 12 category B pictures and 19 category C photographs on WhatsApp. The offences are contrary to sections 1(1)(a) and 6 of the Protection of Children Act 1978, and if found guilty, he could receive a maximum penalty of six months imprisonment and/or an unlimited fine.\n\nEdwards has now reportedly moved out of his family home in Dulwich, south London that he stared with Vicky. He is said to have moved to another home in the capital and has been splitting his time between there and his native Wales. Edwards is due at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.\n\nHe is not yet believed to have divorced from Flind, who he shares three sons and two daughters with. Huw has been living elsewhere for a while.\" Edwards and Ms Flind got engaged in 1993 and are said to have met when he was 30 and working as a BBC correspondent in Westminster. Ms Flind is two years his junior and has worked on shows including ITV's Peston and BBC One's This Week.\n\nThis is a breaking showbiz news story. Legal papers suggest the allegations concern 37 pictures discovered on a child's mobile device, exchanged on a WhatsApp conversation between December 2020 and April 2022.\n\nEdwards was taken into custody on November 8, 2023, and formally accused on June 26, 2024, after approval from the Crown Prosecution Service. He is scheduled to appear at Westminster Magistrates' Court on Wednesday.\n\nWho is Huw Edwards?\n\nHuw Edwards has worked as a TV reporter for 30 years, mainly recognized for hosting BBC News at Ten, the most-viewed news program in Britain. He was raised in Llangennech, Carmarthenshire, and attended Llanelli Grammar School before pursuing higher education. Currently, he resides in London with his spouse and five offspring. Huw Edwards completed his studies at Cardiff University with a diploma in French. He also possesses honorary fellowships from Cardiff University, Swansea University, and the University of Wales, Lampeter, as well as an honorary doctorate from the University of Glamorgan. Edwards has hosted coverage of significant occasions, such as the London 2012 Olympic Games, the Royal Wedding (for which he was awarded a BAFTA for Best Coverage of a Live Event), and the swearing-in of US President Barack Obama. He departed from the BBC in April this year. He has also presented various programs on history and classical music on different BBC channels. His documentaries have delved into notable historical figures like David Lloyd George, Gladstone, Disraeli, and Owain Glyndwr. His series The Story of Wales was especially praised, serving as the first television history of Wales in 25 years and garnering multiple accolades.", "source": {"uri": "pehalnews.in", "dataType": {"uri": "8249338824", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-29", "time": "17:36:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-29T17:36:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-29T17:35:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.47843137383461, "url": "https://guernseypress.com/news/uk-news/2024/07/29/huw-edwards-former-bbc-presenter-was-one-of-the-most-prominent-faces-on-tv/", "title": "Huw Edwards: Former BBC presenter was one of the most prominent faces on TV", "body": "On Monday, the Metropolitan Police confirmed the former presenter has been charged with making indecent images of children.\n\nHuw Edwards was one of the most recognisable faces on British television, having anchored coverage of major national events and presented the BBC's News At Ten for decades.\n\nThe 62-year-old fronted the flagship nightly news programme for the last 20 years, earning a reputation as a respected veteran broadcaster, before he resigned from the corporation in April.\n\nOn Monday, the Metropolitan Police confirmed the former presenter has been charged with making indecent images of children.\n\nEdwards faces three charges over alleged activity between December 2020 and April 2022 and is due in court on Wednesday.\n\nDuring his four decades at the corporation, he was among the broadcasting teams leading coverage of historic events including the late Queen's funeral in 2022 and most recently the coronation of the King in May 2023.\n\nEdwards, a married father of five, also announced the late Queen's death on the BBC in September 2022.\n\nOver the years he was the BBC's go-to presenter for big news events and was front and centre in live broadcasts of election coverage, the Queen's Diamond Jubilee in 2012 and Platinum Jubilee in 2022, the wedding of the then Duke and Duchess of Cambridge in 2011, the wedding of the Duke and Duchess of Sussex in 2018, and the funeral of the Duke of Edinburgh in 2021.\n\nHe was also the BBC's voice at Trooping the Colour and the Festival of Remembrance.\n\nEdwards was a Westminster correspondent for 13 years and played a key role in the BBC's political reporting, taking over election coverage from the long-serving David Dimbleby in 2019.\n\nHe told Radio Times in 2019: \"I'm going to let you in on a secret: the first time a senior BBC manager dangled this carrot in front of me was in 1992. So it's been at the back of my mind since then.\"\n\nThis last salary marked an increase from 2022/23, when he was paid between \u00a3435,000 and 439,999 for 180 days presenting on BBC One, as well as news specials.\n\nIn 2018, it was reported he agreed to take a pay cut following revelations over unequal pay for men and women at the BBC.\n\nEdwards said in 2021 that he was considering his future presenting News At Ten as he approached his 60th birthday.\n\n\"A time comes when you're bound to reassess what's in front of you,\" he told Radio Cymru in a Welsh-language interview.\n\n\"Now that a big milestone is here, which is 60 years old, it's natural for a man to think 'Am I going to continue in this job for another five years, or do I want to do something different?'\n\n\"The nightly news business, after 20 years, that can be taxing, even though I still enjoy the job.\n\n\"I don't think I'll be doing that for long. Because I believe that, in the first place, I think it's fair for the viewers to get a change.\n\n\"Secondly, I have co-workers who are very talented - it's time to give them a chance too.\"\n\nHe added: \"I won't disappear tomorrow from the 10 o'clock news because I'm still enjoying myself.\n\n\"But of course, I'm thinking about the working patterns of the future. And the truth is that I don't want to sustain these working patterns for a long time to come, because I don't believe it's a very wise thing at all.\"\n\nAn article on the BBC website in 2002 said Edwards was determined to stamp his own identity on News At Ten.\n\n\"You don't want to let people down, but at the same time, I want to do it in my own way. I don't want to be a clone of Sissons or Buerk,\" he said.\n\nEdwards, who attended Llanelli Grammar School and graduated in French from Cardiff University, is an honorary professor in the School of Journalism, Media and Culture at his old university.\n\nEdwards is listed as a vice president on the website of the National Churches Trust and has appeared on Songs Of Praise.\n\nHe has also made documentaries for the BBC including Wales: Who Do We Think We Are? and talked about his depression on S4C's Huw Edwards Is 60.\n\nIn a documentary in 2021, Edwards revealed he has had bouts of depression over the last two decades which have left him \"bedridden\".\n\n\"Like everyone that suffers with depression, you don't get one bout of it. It comes and goes,\" he said.\n\n\"For me, it started around 2002 I think. I went down fairly quickly and I couldn't understand it.\"\n\nSpeaking on a podcast hosted by Jane Garvey and Fi Glover, Fortunately... With Fi And Jane, he said he decided to share publicly that he has depression as he felt it was \"complete hypocrisy\" to support organisations such as the Shawmind Foundation or Mind without explaining why.\n\n\"I also felt that it might be someway helpful to people if I opened up about it and say, 'You can do a job and you can be successful', whether it's just reading a bit of autocue or doing whatever it is... while also dealing with issues like that,\" he told the podcast.", "source": {"uri": "guernseypress.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Guernsey Press"}, "authors": [], This notifies members of the media that a first court appearance is imminent to allow them to report on it, in accordance with the principles of open justice.\n\n\"I'm therefore puzzled that the CPS did not announce charges when they were brought in June, as at that point it became a public matter.\"\n\nA CPS spokesperson said: \"Decisions on charging announcements are based on operational factors and no defendant receives preferential treatment.\n\n\"Our handling of this case followed our normal procedures working in partnership with police colleagues.\"\n\nScotland Yard denied it had taken a different approach in informing the media in the case of Edwards.\n\nA spokesman for the Metropolitan Police said: \"The approach taken in this case isn't unusual.\n\n\"Quite often when there {"uri": "8252010275", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "08:06:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T08:06:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T08:05:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.4156862795352936, "url": "https://www.thetimes.com/uk/media/article/huw-edwards-splits-wife-vicky-flind-jrzmmnqdv", "title": "Huw Edwards 'splits from wife' Vicky Flind", "body": "Staff were left \"staggered\" this week after it emerged that Edwards, 62, had been charged with making indecent images of children between December 2020 and April 2022. He is due to appear in Westminster magistrates' court on Wednesday.\n\nHe quit the corporation on medical grounds in April, having been suspended over a separate incident last summer in which he was accused of paying a young person and receiving sexual images. At the time, the police found no evidence of criminal behaviour.\n\nStaff were said to be in the dark about his arrest by the Metropolitan police in November and its decision to charge him four weeks ago until the news emerged on Monday.\n\nOne former senior executive said that it would be \"very hard\" for the BBC to ignore pressure to recoup the money it paid to Edwards if he kept his arrest secret.\n\n\"If they knew nothing until this week, then they ought to go after him on a failure to disclose while they were keeping him on full pay,\" they said. \"It would seem odd for them to do nothing.\"\n\nStaffers have expressed their anger about the allegations, which has been compounded by their timing, days after Tim Davie, BBC director-general delivered the corporation's annual report.\n\nIt simultaneously revealed that Edwards had been handed a pay rise of about \u00a340,000 before his suspension, taking his salary up to a maximum of \u00a3479,000, and the need for the corporation to cut 500 roles by March 2026 as it seeks to make \u00a3500 million of annual savings.\n\nThis week BBC News launched an \"accelerated voluntary redundancy\" scheme. \"They are about to make 500 people redundant. Huw's pay rise could have saved a couple of jobs. His salary could have saved a lot more. It's not rocket science,\" one staffer said.\n\n\"People here feel like there are two very separate groups of staff who are treated very differently. The 'talent' are paid a fortune ... while the 'grafters' work all hours, wouldn't dream of asking for any more than the minimum pay rise and are too scared to call out bad behaviour because when we do we risk becoming part of 'the awkward squad'.\"\n\nOthers were sceptical about whether the BBC had the \"stomach\" to try to recover any money even if it was legally entitled to.\n\n\"They are so profligate,\" one presenter said. \"Everything is ruled by HR these days and they play by different rules to everyone else.\"\n\nAnother added: \"He just received a sizeable pay increase but they don't appear to have made any moves to claw it back so far and I don't see how they can.\"\n\nThere were also concerns about the potential impact of such action on Edwards' mental health, after his resignation on medical grounds.\n\nA BBC insider said that it was unclear if Edwards was under any obligation to inform bosses about his arrest or charge. \"As far as we are concerned he is history -- he is no longer an employee and we don't owe him any duty of care any longer,\" they added.\n\n\"And just because he is alleged to have committed these offences doesn't mean that we had any knowledge or responsibility for them.\"\n\nThe unrest has topped a challenging period for the BBC, which is preparing for the findings of an internal review about how competitors on Strictly Come Dancing were treated by their professional dance partners following a complaint by the actor Amanda Abbington.\n\n\"We just lurch from one crisis to the next,\" one staffer said.", "source": {"uri": guilty to making indecent images of children", "body": "LONDON: Former BBC news anchor Huw Edwards, one of the most recognisable faces on UK television, on Wednesday pleaded guilty to three counts of making indecent images of children.\n\nThe 62-year-old, who resigned from the BBC in April on \"medical advice\", six months after he was initially arrested, faces a maximum prison sentence of 10 years and a minimum of 12 months.\n\nGet exclusive content with Gulf News WhatsApp channel\n\nWearing a dark suit and blue tie, Edwards was emotionless as he admitted having 41 indecent images of children on WhatsApp, including seven of the most serious type.\n\nThe offences were committed between December 2020 and August 2021, amended from the initial chargesheet which ran to April 2022.\n\nAlso read British TV doctor Mosley found dead on Greek island of Symi British police get 100 million pounds to tackle knife crime surge Making a case for private prosecutions European police crack encrypted phones, arrest hundreds\n\nWestminster Magistrates' Court in London heard that Edwards had received 377 sexual images from a man on WhatsApp, of which 41 were indecent images of children.\n\nOf the most serious images, the estimated age of most of the children was between 13 and 15, but one was aged between seven and nine, the court was told.\n\nEdwards had told the man not to send any illegal images, the court heard.\n\nHe was released on conditional bail until his next hearing on September 16, when he could be sentenced.\n\nEdwards was the BBC's lead presenter on key events, such as the death and funeral of Queen Elizabeth II, but was suspended in July 2023 when allegations first emerged.\n\nHe had also been the anchor of the BBC's flagship 10:00 pm news programme since 2003.\n\nHe quit on April 22 after 40 years with the broadcaster.\n\nAs the accusations became front-page news last July, Edwards's wife Vicky Flind said the father-of-five was \"suffering from serious mental health issues\" and had been admitted to hospital.\n\nEdwards himself has not publicly commented on the allegations.\n\nThe BBC's brand has been built on public trust but the broadcaster has been rocked in recent years by scandals which saw some big names revealed as serial sex offenders.", "source": {"uri": "gulfnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "GULF NEWS"}, {"uri": "8252751595", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-31", "time": "15:47:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-31T15:47:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-31T15:43:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6823529601097107, "url": "https://www.yahoo.com/news/huw-edwards-former-bbc-news-091638537.html", "title": "Huw Edwards, Former BBC News Anchor, Pleads Guilty to Making Indecent Images of Children", "body": "Update: The BBC has issued a statement about Huw Edwards' guilty plea. A spokesperson said the corporation was \"shocked\" to hear of the details that emerged in court on Wednesday and that Edwards was no longer a BBC employee when he was charged, having resigned two months earlier. Read the full statement below.\n\nPreviously: Huw Edwards has pled guilty to three charges of making indecent images of children during his first appearance in a U.K. court.\n\nMore from Variety\n\nOn Wednesday morning, Edwards appeared at Westminster Magistrates Court in London to acknowledge the charges before Chief Magistrate Paul Goldspring and a packed press gallery.\n\nThe former BBC news anchor, who was once one of the highest paid figures at the BBC, showed no emotion as he was led through Courtroom 1 and into the glass-panelled dock, dressed in a dark suit, white shirt and blue tie. While he entered the courthouse in dark sunglasses, he had removed these before entering the court.\n\nEdwards spoke only to give his name, date of birth and his partial U.K. address, to enter his plea for each charge and to confirm he understood the bail conditions. His counsel requested that, in contravention of U.K. court tradition, Edwards should not read out his full address due to the \"volatile\" situation outside the court which included protests.\n\nThe prosecutor explained how the images were sent to him via WhatsApp by \"an adult man who contacted Mr Edwards on social media.\" They were automatically saved to his phone. Edwards asked the WhatsApp sender to stop sending \"illegal\" images of underage children. The chat continued thereafter with \"further legal pornographic images\" being sent.\n\nThe charges related to 41 images and videos that were shared on the messaging site between 2020 and 2022. Six of those were Category A, considered the most serious.\n\nThe maximum sentence is 10 years in prison.\n\nThe sentencing has been adjourned until September for a pre-sentence report. In the meantime, Edwards has been released on conditional bail.\n\nHis lawyer told the court in mitigation that Edwards was a man \"not only of good character but of exemplary character.\" He also added there were mental health issues at play \"at the time of the offending and now.\" The lawyer was also keen to emphasize that Edwards had not \"made\" any images or videos in the \"traditional\" sense.\n\nThe news anchor, who had spent 40 years at the BBC, resigned in April citing medical advice. He had been on a 10-month absence of leave after a tabloid newspaper revealed a senior presenter at the BBC had been involved in a sex photo scandal. Although Edwards was not initially named, after rumors reached fever pitch his wife made a statement confirming the BBC anchor was implicated and had checked into a hospital for mental health treatment.\n\nRead the BBC's full statement below:\n\nThe BBC is shocked to hear the details which have emerged in court today. There can be no place for such abhorrent behaviour and our thoughts are with all those affected.\n\nThe police have confirmed that the charges are not connected to the original complaint raised with the BBC in the summer of 2023, nevertheless in the interests of transparency we think it important to set out some points about events of the last year.\n\nIn November 2023, whilst Mr Edwards was suspended, the BBC as his employer at the time was made aware in confidence that he had been arrested on suspicion of serious offences and released on bail whilst the police continued their investigation. At the time, no charges had been brought against Mr Edwards and the BBC had also been made aware of significant risk to his health.\n\nToday we have learnt of the conclusion of the police process in the details as presented to the court. If at any point during the period Mr Edwards was employed by the BBC he had been charged, the BBC had determined it would act immediately to dismiss him. In the end, at the point of charge he was no longer an employee of the BBC.\n\nDuring this period, in the usual way, the BBC has kept its corporate management of these issues separate from its
